151217789.review:
[i]Volcano Princess[/i] is a very endearing life sim title. To echo the actual store page description, the player assumes the role of the father of the lovely little angel Rose (I went with the default given name in my first playthrough) and by his actions [spoiler](and her own later on in life)[/spoiler], will shape what kind of woman she grows into come adulthood. There are actually a fair number of endings present, which I will gloss on slightly a bit later.

[h3]PROS:[/h3]
+ The simplicity of [i]starting[/i]. The game begins fairly easily, with mechanics being easy to understand - it’s mostly point-and-click throughout. However, the depth of Volcano Princess lies with all the various ways of growing Basic and Core attributes, developing Natural Skills and relationships with the various townspeople, and even acquiring hidden conditions (called “Darkness”) when nurturing Rose. Essentially, every action taken is factored into how the ending will turn out. Because of how free the player is in deciding their virtual daughter’s future, Rose can actually become either a very good, or very bad person. Though, why would you ever want the latter, goodness gracious.

+ There is a simple combat system in place which is only available when one chooses the Explore option while at the Forgotten Valley. Fairly straightforward and not tedious. Though maybe too simple for some. Successfully completing quests will advance Rose’s Knight Career, something which gets introduced pretty early in the story.

+ The gorgeous artwork is one of the game’s biggest draws. Very adorable and lovely, and the various scenes spaced throughout the main and relationship stories are nicely done too.

+ At the start of each day, the player is able to interact with Rose, with the frequency increasing as she matures. She is actually fully voiced for all these interactions. As of writing this, there are choices for Japanese or Chinese voices.

+ The music is sweet. As expected of a game of this genre, it is calming, with fantasy tones befitting the setting. The various ambience presented is fairly soothing and relaxing to listen to on loop, in some areas.

+ Developing relationships will influence the end game. Not simply who her future spouse(s) will be, but if I’m not mistaken, it is also factored into what sort of career Rose will have. There exists a decent range of characters whom Rose can interact with and befriend. Some offer her jobs, others sell her clothing or equipment, and of course there are also those who can be recruited to join her party for explorations.

+ The English translation is fairly good, with only minor inaccuracies in certain dialogues. And it’s not all incorrect per se either, just, not the most suitable to use at times.

[h3]NEUTRALS:[/h3]
+/- There isn’t much explanation of an overall, overarching story currently, despite it being sort of hinted at in the prologue, and here and there throughout the game’s progress. While there are pieces of lore fillers, it currently lacks a cohesive structure. This could be a feature expanded upon by the developers, on a later date. Or even be the premise for a second title in the series? I hope so, either way.

[h3]CONS:[/h3]
- If you are a completionist, then you will be playing this game for a long, long while, considering the multitude of endings. However, if you’re the sort to enjoy that, or just adore the simple fact of raising a child like Rose, then I suppose this is actually a big [b]PRO[/b] instead.

[h2]VERDICT:[/h2]
A very wholesome take on the life sim genre, Volcano Princess will charm you with its lovely main character and delightful setting. You’ll be spending quite a bit of time exploring the various ways to go about parenting darling Rose. And at the end, you might even shed some genuine tears.

Indulging in this serene and therapeutic gaming experience, I found myself immersed in a captivating daughter-raising simulation. The game's enchanting art style boasts an undeniable cuteness factor. The music also creates a cozy ambiance that enhances the overall experience.

The stat-raising system was easily understandable. The game's intricate web of outcomes and multiple endings provides satisfying unpredictability. The prospect of exploring various paths and witnessing diverse conclusions makes the game inherently replayable.

However, there was a single drawback: the absence of Steam sync. Transitioning between PCs became a tad frustrating, as my progress didn't seamlessly carry over.

In conclusion, I wholeheartedly recommend this gem to fellow gamers seeking a delightful blend of relaxation, charm, and replayability. It's a whimsical journey worth embarking on, with its endearing visuals, soothing music, and the joy of shaping your own unique narrative within the game.

this game is sort of like long live the queen but with a lot less political intrigue and random assassination attempts. This is a very cute and fun game.

The dark play-through hurt me in the feels a bit, but I did it to raise the Demon Queen!

149897108.review:
You might be tempted to ignore this one because the translation is really bad in places -- in fact, there's a hilariously immersion-breaking mistake right at the end that gets repeated over and over in the last fifteen minutes of play.

But if you can look beyond that, there's a surprisingly deep story hidden here that goes well beyond the standard "life milestones and daddy feelings" that you can get from any daughter-raising sim. Likewise, some of the interactions you can have with other villagers as you get to know them are genuinely touching.

It might not seem like much is going on at first, but if you know the genre tropes and start following them early, you can get the true ending in the first playthrough (that said, the true ending is probably even better with a certain romance path which might not be obvious.)

Some of the game's systems fall short for me (certain special event mini-games are a good idea but not great execution) but all in all I was pleasantly surprised at how this game breathes new life into a framework that's been done so many times, even the recent Princess Maker games are falling flat.

If you like this kind of game, odds are good you'll love Volcano Princess.

148606306.review:
I love this game, I hope people come to think of it as a classic of the fantasy life-sim genre like Princess Maker or Cute Knight.

There's plenty to do, the writing is enjoyable, and the art is beautiful.

Like the original English release of Princess Maker, the translation is occasionally charmingly wobbly, but I always understood what it was trying to say - it's mostly some characters and places having a few variant spellings of their names (e.g. Lon/Ron, Alan/Ellen).

If you're an ending collector like me, the game helpfully lets you pick from the best ending of each "type" you qualify for, which is a great quality of life feature. Maybe my daughter does want to spend her entire childhood fighting monsters and then retire to become an amateur actress. The 35 hours I've clocked at the moment is four "full" runs of the game, plus some reloading to see different ending variations.

147962151.review:
If I would describe this game, it's an spiritual successor to the legendary Princess Maker series and I love Princess Maker. I played PM 2, 3 and 5 for the most part, with PM3 being my most favorite and PM2 not far behind.

You played as "Wood" the father. The end game is to raise your daughter "Rose", guide her to various decision and watch her as she slowly transition from child to adulthood. You raising your daughter by balancing the resource, mostly Money and Action Point, to allocate your daughter stats, relationship with NPC, romancing marriage candidates both boys and girls, juggling your daughter moods, choosing which class she goes, horse racing, cooking, fight street thug, fight monster, fight demon, fight your friend, fight god, play dress up, meet important people, play dice, went acting, do alchemy, do math, and etc.... 

With these much variety ways (side gameplay) of raising your daughter, the good news here is you won't have to deal with these all at once. The game did a pretty good job introducing and getting used to them as the time goes.

At it's core, Volcano Princess is a visual novel with a couple of mini games littered in between. Whatever decision you pick will slow affect your virtual daughter over the course of 8-12 hrs and where she will ended up. The game has many replayability. Many endings and loads of save slot at your disposal. RNG does influence the result from time to time. Save scumming can be an option for completionist. But I would recommend to go blind and try many mechanic this tiny game has to offer for the first run, then you can start doing min-maxing later.

Voice acting is great, with both original Chinese and recently Japanese. Despite mostly limited to important sentence and your daughter. I'm not proficient at both language so I might be wrong, but I can feels the character well. The music well suited the game theme, usually clam and serene with an alright action music when things get heated in fight. The art is real good and consistence through most game some really beg to have a thumbnail or wallpaper. The mugshot and chibi icon really cute. Although, I kinda do wish all the NPC, beside Nina, can have an art or sprite as a children to growing along with the daughter, otherwise everyone just look either teenager and adult through out the whole game.

Unlike Princess Maker, however, Volcano Princess is safe for all devoted christian and all age which ever decision you may choose. :)

To end the review, I overall gave this game 8/10. The only complain is that I felt the "True Ending" is a bit overwhelming, coming from me a PM fans, the way of achieving wise. And with 8-12 hrs per game is about OK, I do prefer a more arcade feels 3-5 hrs of PM 2 and 3 of a full play through (I'm looking at you PM5... I'm not a very save scummy person when it comes to this kind of game, but with a realistic pacing of 40+ hrs per playthough with many many possible ending!!? I know you would love to be the most comprehensive raising daughter game ever but come on now!). 

Some may complain about the english translation quality. While, yes, it does have some issues, mostly to do with conveying the emotion (lost in translation?). The text clipped off the textbox from time to time. I personally found the English does it job for the most part. They honestly did a much better job than CFK's Princess Maker half-arse translation, which sometimes do affect the game play in significant way. But here what we have is perfectly fine for the most part.

Other than that, this game is a blast to go through. It makes you care and anticipate whatever in game NPC interaction can makes you overall feels good and real relax game. I'm happy for what I'm getting and a kind of game I can casually come back from time to time. :)

147260631.review:
[b]9/10[/b]

A very relaxing and cute game. There are so many ways to raise the daughter and so many things to do in volcanic country, that it's overwhelming. She can turn into a criminal or a queen, depending on your choices. She can romance anyone, even from the same sex, as well as have polygamous relationships. The game is full of choices, content, and heart.

Unfortunately, there are some significant flaws in the game. The biggest of these (and the cause of a lot of issues) is the not-so-good translation of the game. It can cause misunderstandings about the gameplay instructions, make the dialogue feel uninteresting (which can make the game feel a bit draggy), and it makes the game feel very rough around the edges. Due to a lot of mistranslated text, some mechanics (like the dice game) are impossible to understand. 

If you want to play a wholesome game with a lot of great content, art, mechanics, and choices (and dialogue), this will fit perfectly. It is very playable even with the bad translation, it just keeps the game from being a masterpiece.

This is such a cute and captivating game. The artworks is fantastic and the music is so sweet and romantic. If there is one consistent thing that is bothering me, it is the English translation. There are so many grammar and spelling errors, it is hard to read, sometimes. Also, some situations call for you to choose between "ignore him" or "endure" and I don't think the game makers knew what those words meant for that situation. 

There is a time when a character who doesn't know how to write, sends you a letter expressing their feelings. When I first read it, I immediately thought, "oh man, this game's translation is getting worse," until they revealed in the letter that they couldn't write. The point: I didn't think the game was actually trying to portray an illiterate character. This is because the game has many poor English translations throughout that it takes you out of the game so much you find yourself coping with it more than you think. 

If there is some way to spend some of the revenue this game made to get a real English translator to redo the script, this would go a long way to make this game long remembered for fans... Especially those that remember Princess Maker, which had a wonderful translation.

145701102.review:
This review is written from the point of view of someone who has loved the Princess Maker series since discovering Princess Maker 2 in early 2000s.

If you do not know this series you might be wondering why am I bringing up an entirely different game franchise when making a review about Volcano Princess.

You see, Volcano Princess is sorta a spiritual sequel to the Princess Maker series. A franchise of games where a father (you) obtains a daughter in some way and has to do his best to keep her safe and so that she grows up into a wonderful woman that will find her way through life.

I am not gonna go into too much detail about the mechanics and such as I feel figuring them out is half of the experience here but yes, this is basically Princess Maker 6.

Sadly similarly to Princess Maker series, it has a pretty bad English translation. If you cannot deal with that, then this might not be a game for you. It also has a rather strange saving system where you can only save at the start of the month. There is also a lot of RNG to combat, especially in the final dungeon where your daughter and her companions can just get stunned to death or instantly gibbed by certain enemies.

But, everything else is basically positive. When I played the game I have truly felt not just for my daughter Sylvie, but also for her father Fin (me) and all of the people of the Volcano Country. Where Princess Maker games kinda fail is secondary NPCs and Volcano Princess truly shines here. I will probably remember some of the people here forever, honestly.

Music is wonderful, only had one crash in an entire playthrough that I streamed over at my Twitch channel and generally the game plays well.

You can see the entire playthrough over at my Youtube channel, just look up Volcano Princess Fingusa and you should be able to see for yourself.

Thank you, developers. You have made a wonderful game and should be proud.

145177238.review:
This isn't a bad game. On the contrary, it's charming, cute, and has a lot of content for the asking price. However, I'm not giving it a recommendation because it isn't what it advertises itself as - a dad simulator.

You really only play as the dad for a tiny amount of time at the very beginning of the game (which amounts to just a tutorial of sorts) and then you promptly exit your daughter's life as the game fast forwards to her teens. It then becomes a school life simulator as you play as the daughter who balances classes, relationships, part-time jobs, and the occasional foray into the nearby forest.

Sure, the daughter still comes home every now and again at which point the dad can talk to her or give her advice (once per day), but that is not only optional in most cases, but is also less the dad raising the daughter and more of a game mechanic to choose which stat to raise while still actually playing as the daughter.

If that's your cup of tea, then by all means, play the game. I think it's worth the asking price. But if you're looking for something other than just another school life pseudo dating simulator, then you'll be disappointed.

144052517.review:
Huh.  I like this.  It's really kind good!  I'm also not sure exactly where to start.

Cons:  The English translation isn't the greatest and can lead to some mistakes when choosing dialogue lines.  The mini-games don't feel fully explained or were just awkward with no muscle memory to apply, and I whiiffed on most of them.  

Pros:  I usually play adult games and this came up on my feed and it is NOT an adult game (No I didn't expect it to be, but it was recommended based on my games played, which I thought was weird).  It's a cute child-raising game where you essentially level up the daughter and prepare her for life.   The artwork is great and the story was fairly engaging and cute.  There is a game + where you can buff up your stats to replay and get additional endings.

Word of warning, it's possible to achieve endless action points (the ability to do things in your turn), and when you purchased from the blacksmith dude... you build a relationship with him that ends up with the daughter marrying the son, at least in some scenarios, so word of warning.  I was disappointed when I discovered it and had no way to cut it off.

A key thing for ending are the attributes of stamina, mind, and charisma.   Lessons and a few other things help to build.  You also have other stats like strength, imagination, Emotional intelligence (I assume), and something else.   These determine how easy your lessons will be and are also gating elements for jobs and maybe other things every time you level those states, you get to upgrade your skills which makes the game easier.

I'd say a second play-through is required because I'll be surprised if someone plays with zero errors due to the translation.  Still, it is mostly understandable and enjoyable.

time played:  21 hours first play through although about three-four hours was building up cash/action points and massively building up stats as much as I could.  I still have a few more endings to do before my play-through, 

Value?:   I'd say yes either on sale or not.  I think it went on sale and that's why I pulled the trigger, but I'm not 100%.   Either way it is worth it.

So, do I recommend it?  Yes.   I purchased it on a whim because I wanted something different, and this worked well.  Check out other reviews and the images to make sure this type of game would appeal to you, but if you are interested based on my description of some gameplay elements (not going to cover all of them as there are quite a few and it depends on your paths) then I'd say to go for it.

143621340.review:
[h1]Volcano Princess Review[/h1]

    If you buy this game you will be able to enjoy it for hours provided you do not get burnt out from the repetitiveness. Your goal in the game is to raise/guide your daughter until she is an adult. Making her study/engage in different activities will influence her attributes. A different combination of attributes or level of these attributes will determine her adult life. Every day make sure you plan what you want to do to make her the happiest (or not)! There seems to be not only many different endings but also different romance pairing endings depending on how your daughter’s attributes are built(can romance both boy and girl and poly ending). There are also many items you can unlock after beating the game. There is a gallery with a collection just 100% this game will take a lot of hours. This leaves you with many hours of enjoyment getting your money back. However this can lead to burnt out. The relative structure of each playthrough and some events are fixed, what will be different is the different way you want to guide your daughter. Do you want her to be more combat focused? Or maybe guide her to be a lady? Do this by choosing different knight paths at the beginning of her school years and choosing different activities. Players who play VNs, or other life sim type games or games with life sims aspects (persona, fire emblem three houses) are familiar with this repetition but can get tiring if played for too long. I often felt myself going onto autopilot when playing for a long session forgetting that even though I was focused on trying to complete one goal I was ignoring the other important stats. I would advise you to take a break. (also thank God for the skip button for multiple playthroughs!!) 
   The translation from chinese to english is really not the best but playable. You can definitely tell it was translated literally from chinese at some places. You can get the general idea of the main story and what the characters are saying. Lore from NPC or friendship candidates events will give more background into the setting. The events are nice and some are cuter/have a more romantic undertone than the others. You do feel bad when high friendship characters send you a sad letter when you pick another person over them to marry. Even though it took a lot to process what was happening in the true story due to the unclear translation I can get the idea but I am still a little confused by it but I do not think this game is played for the main story anyways.  Before when you start there is little tutorial text you can read and after there are little question marks you can mouse over if you do not understand some parts of the gameplay or stats but this game does not handhold you. I liked being able to play the game/figure out how the game works for me.
You might also need a walkthrough to get all the endings or if you beat the game once the archive will tell you what stats are needed to unlock that career path. I would advise you to use the note feature on the steam overlay and write down which career path you are aiming for and the requirements.

[b]CREEPY DAD SECTION?[/b]
Those who are wary about playing as a Dad well once your daughter turns to a teen I believe you are playing as both characters the Dad and the daughter. Especially during the in town segments you are playing as the daughter. (I think we are the daughter because the Dad does not know the daughter’s friends even if we give her pocket money it disappears from the UI…). So I like the idea that we are guiding the daughter now instead of raising her. She is free to choose her own path, the Dad is not forcing her. I did not feel creepy at all at being a Dad character and felt the daughter was more self insert than the Dad. Secondly, the Dad really loves the Mom from what I can understand from the true ending and the home part of the end game bonuses section. The game did not influence me at all to be a real Dad except maybe at the end a little at the end XI JINPING SORRY!

[b]Conclusion[/b] 
Volcano Princess is a good game that is worth the price for the time you can play. While this game can have a lot of repetition there is a lot of replay value with the different career paths and knight path you can choose and different stat routes. If the English translation was professionally proficient (this is something that can change, hopefully fixed in the future!), I could see this game becoming bigger in the West with streamers. Buy this game if you like life sims with many different endings and things to unlock, good art and a lot of soul and heart put into it!

142826416.review:
At the start of the game, please name your daughter carefully. You might regret it if you named her as "xKhaleesix"

Ok, Volcano Princess. Before I bought it, I don't have any clue about this game, but this game kept appearing on my recommendation so I gave it a try. My first impression on playing this game was "oh, maybe this is some kind of otome game that I read in novel/manga/manhwa, I'll just try for below 2 hours before sleep and then refund it laa". At that time I don't have high expectation for this game, then I stopped playing not because it's near 2 hours threshold, I stopped because sunlight already appears on my window.

From the very first minutes, the game's beautiful music instantly drew me in, creating a captivating ambiance. The interaction between the daughter and the father is very sweet, the progression is reinforcing. I really like how I, as a father in this game try to min max my daughter but still keeping her happy because there is a penalty if the daughter's mood is below 50. By playing this game, you could watch the progression of your daughter from childhood to adult, and most of your decision in nurturing her would affect the ending. 

The romanceable characters in this game is a lot, from typical otome game male lead to Mark the regular guard. Even there is a yuri ending here, so there are many options that you could choose. 

The negative aspect of this game is, the save system. It only save your data at the beginning of the month, even if you save your data in the middle of your activities. So it's frustrating if you want to stop playing, but you still in the middle of your activities. 

In conclusion, Volcano Princess delivers an emotionally satisfying journey alongside a developing daughter . It's a game that surprises and delights, with a variety of choices and outcomes that will keep players coming back for more. Whether you're a fan of otome games or just looking for an engaging and heartwarming experience, this game is well worth your time.

142797505.review:
This is a wonderful and beautiful game, and I fully recommend it to anyone. 
HOWEVER! there are a few caveats.
-Steam description is quite misleading. According to it, this is a parenting simulation, where you play the father, and your actions only indirectly influence daughter's life. And this is true - for a first chapter of a game. But then it quickly switches to directly controlling daughter, who essentially became the PC, with father mostly doing the side jobs on a backstage. This throws down the immersion, and kinda takes the most interesting part from the promise.
-This is a translated game, and it shows. It handles simple conversations and descriptions pretty fine, but even after careful re-reading I still have only a vague understanding of what was the truth behind the main plot mystery. 
-Gameplay, while not difficult, is quite... esotheric. There are multiple sub-systems which are related in a non-intuitive way, like Strength and Endurance belonging to two entirely different systems of stats. This can (and will) be quite hard to comprehend. For example despite heavily focusing on Combat path, winning Royal Tournament, finishing all the adventures numerous times, having great martial stats and completing hell of a lot of combat-orientated courses, I wasn't offered any half-descent military career in the ending. Which might be realistic, but is still frustrating.
...but in the end, all of it doesn't matter. 
What does matter is that this game made me care. Made me worry. Made me try really hard to get the best result.
Made me cry.
Made me call my ma, and for once express her how much I love her, how grateful I am to her for all she has done for me.
This is why I will end my review with the same words I’ve started it:
This is a wonderful and beautiful game, and I fully recommend it to anyone.

142626462.review:
This game punishes players for not having a crystal ball and spreadsheet to exhaustively plan out what to do to get the best endings.

It tells players that certain endings require a high enough subject score - this is fine - but then it bars them from reaching that score if they don't do a specific thing two-thirds through the run.

The game works as follows:
- Your daughter has 4 basic attributes, 3 core attributes and 8 subject scores.
- During a turn, she spends action points on activities to earn money and fame, and improve basic attributes and relationships.
- At the end of a turn, she takes up to 5 Courses (reading books or attending lessons) to improve basic attributes, core attributes and subject scores.
- Each ending requires her to reach a specific threshold of attributes and subject scores before graduation (about 36 turns from the time of enrolment).
- More Courses are unlocked through books gifted by NPCs, improving relationships with the 4 teachers, and buying master classes.

Where the game fails is that you can run out of Courses before you run out of turns.

I wanted to get the 'Queen' ending, which requires a score of 500 (C+) in every subject. With about 6 turns to go (June), I realised that I'm 20 points short in Science and there's no more Science course to take. I rolled back to an earlier save (February) but no matter what I did, I still came up 20 points short. I'd already exhausted all the aforementioned ways to unlock more Courses. Reading discussions online, it seems that I should've bought a Science master class. But they're only available to buy 3 times a year and I'd already bought the 'wrong' classes in January.

So I had unwittingly locked myself out of the Queen ending with 12 turns to spare. All because I didn't work out which subjects needed to be supplemented by master classes. Too bad. Return to square one. Bring a spreadsheet next time.

In the end, all it took was one bad design choice to ruin my entire experience with the game. Perhaps you won't encounter the same problem, but don't say you weren't warned.

142274372.review:
This game reminds me a lot of Princess Maker 2. I played that game to death back in the day, and I'm so happy to find a game that is worthy not of just being a successor but even better than it. In the game, you raise your daughter. It sounds simple, but the game is a complex fabric of planning your daughter's interactions, which kind of interactions she should have, the skills she should develop, her mood, her fame, her 'darkness', your wealth, and how many action points you have for the day. There are numerous possible endings and a New Game+ mode in which you can increase your daughter's starting stats. See how your actions affect her future and her future selves as you raise ... well, whomever you want.

I can't praise this game enough. The gameplay is fantastic, with six mini-games to play as well (combat, mathematics game, two different dice games, horse racing, and a 'painting' game). The audio is adorable, although only available in Chinese and Japanese. The art is charming, memorable, and consistently high quality. My single complaint would be that the English localization is slightly rough around the edges in some places, e.g. "don' t" instead of "don't" and some NPC name spelling inconsistencies. You'll be too busy farming, stuffing your daughter's face with bread, racing horses, keeping her from being evil, and battling monsters in the forest to notice. You'll get a sense of fulfillment out of seeing your plans succeed and your daughter reach your goals all the while developing relationships with more than a dozen NPCs.

This game is worth your time. Buy it. Make a princess. Or not. That's the best part.

142216294.review:
Man, this is one of the 39583 games that shows that Steam really should introduce a midly recommended button.

This a very good game.  If it was in early acess.

Th entire game feels like it's an Alpha. A very playable alpha mind you, but an Alpha. Like, most of the game's content feel shallow, one way or another, or straight up unfinished. Which wouldn't be that big of a problem if this wasn't the type of game that you're expected to have multiple playthoughs, making the cracks be more apparent the more and more you play. Sometimes you'll see it early in the game, with some game mechanics presented differently than they are currently, almost as if the dev changed how it worked but forgot to change the tutorial text.

Also a big unfinished thing: The translation. It's technically finished, but good lord, it's bad. Like, it's really bad. google translator/literal translation bad. And given that this is a game that was originally chinese... Yeah. The translation sometime get's weird. And given that this is a story driven game, it really hurts your ability appreciate the characters dialogue and their story. For example, there is a character that has difficult speaking. It took my second playthrough to realize that was on purpose and not the translation being bad. 

The translation is also very confusing for the gameplay itself. The same mechancs will be given two different names, sometimes three, making you have to guess what you're even doing.

Which is not to say the game is bad in everything, the art is absolutely gorgeous, there is hundreds of different of beautiful drawn images, there's dozens of endings, dozens of marriage ending, and the game feels engaging enough for the first playthrough, and you get a good attachment to your daughter as she grows up.

So... Yeah. a 6.5/10.

Ps: The dev team is like, 2 people for most of the stuff in it. Which is absolutely insane given the amount of things this game has, as shallow as they may feel. Hopefully with the amount of copies the game sold they can afford to hire a full time dev team, either for a sequel, or to make the current content feel more cohesive and replayable.

Also, for the love of god. I pray they hire a new translator/translation team. The current ones are either scamming the devs, or they are really, really, amateur.

142051652.review:
Ok, bought this with a 15% discount and thought, why not?

The Bad first, there are some strange word choices that makes me wonder if they ran out of money to translate this game into English properly or if the writers simply could not get their story lines straight which led to a somewhat jumbled story telling due to either differences in culture/history/lore between the story tellers and the market audience or some other issues.

Also some parts of the game seem deliberately left rough and undeveloped possibly with an update or DLC sale in the future. (you'll know when you see the huge ass polygons of an otherwise cute anime world).

Its not horrible or totally incomprehensible but your going to have to make some leaps of logic to make the game make sense and prepare for some bad ENRISH SPEEKING from time to time.

Also the game IS simple enough not to need a in-depth tutorial but be prepared to suck at it for a while before you get into the swing of it.

Also if your a fan of Princess Maker (specifically 2 which was my fav game for a time) then its going to feel like a re-release of an old game with a few new graphics and mechanics upgrade.

Now for the good.

It feels like a re-release of Princess Maker 2 with new graphics and mechanics. ^_^

Specially since the new version of Princess Maker 2 had some of its dialogue subtly changed to be more PC from the original and suffers from the same BAD ENRISH from time to time anyway.

Its cute, charming, actually full of characters that aren't irritating caricatures that makes a valiant attempt at being fully fleshed (still somewhat flat given the limits of the game after all), and the story has elements of horror, adventure, drama, romance, high (or low...and poorly rendered) society, school girl life, work and living, gods and goddesses, life/death, the struggles of parenthood and it also subtle and draws you in wonderfully.

Its a game that I somehow stumbled on the True(?) Ending the first time yet I still want to replay this game again to see other branching paths, possibilities and romantic connections that could be had among the characters of the game.

Also despite my near neurotic Tiger Parenting to eek out the best possible stats I could to see Rose rise as high as possible the first time, I didn't quite make it due to inexperience, mistakes  and the cruelty of random numbers so I was surprised by New Game+ mechanic, which coupled with your experience the first time, should allow for a more fun and exploratory second playthrough.

The lure to Aim for the Stars, Again, and Again, until you hit all in the night sky is a great treat.

Be warned though, this game is not just cute tooth rot fodder. There will be times when it gets dark, creepy and made me scream at the screen in rage, fear and frustration.

Specifically when my cute but dumbass kid starts chasing a bird and ignores a cliff.

It...gets better (and worse) from there.

And you'll be glad you stuck through it all.

Edit: I know its not really fitting with the general theme of these types of games but part of me wishes there was a male version now a days. Raising a son instead of a daughter should be feasible enough.

At least it would give a nice contrast and possible unique challenges and mechanic to try.

141817156.review:
This has quickly become my favorite game of this year.  While Volcano Princess is a small game in literal storage size, it's a huge feast of wholesomeness and enjoyment.  The game is all about min-maxing your daughter as her sole parent and watching her progress as she grows up.  It's such a simple concept done [i]so well[/i].  Egg Hatcher (devs) should be proud of this outstanding game.

As for pros and cons
+ A bit of everything; combat, intellect, romance, sorcery...
+ The art is pleasing to the eye, and there's no shortage of art to discover.
+ A generally like-able character set.  I couldn't bring myself to dislike any of the characters. [spoiler]Hacket and Ze have their issues, but still likeable[/spoiler]
+ Significant, widespread depth: Volcano Princess isn't the best at anything it does, but it's the best at combining all of them into a single game.
+ Quality of Life controls, so you aren't trapped reading the same dialogue over and over.
+ Each of the three main paths for the game do actually feel different when replaying.  Going for a charisma build is quite a bit different than brute forcing via a strength build.
+ Entertaining minigames and interesting "challenge-sequences", with a lot of flavor text to help flesh out what are essentially stat-checks.
+++ Incredibly wholesome father-daughter moments.  Many parts genuinely had me smiling out of happiness.
- The English Translation could use some proofreading by a native English-speaker.  Not really that bad.
- Some mechanics could use better explanation, such as "fame", which can be freely spent at the church without damaging ending potentials (not 100% on this, please comment if I am incorrect).
- Horse crash.  The first time you open the menu to catch a horse, the game crashes.  This should be an easily preventable issue, and had me stay away from the game for a while after... before coming back.
- Exploitable/missing mechanics.  Magic materials are pointless, sell them to the smith for extra cash.  [spoiler]Food and fertilizer are stupid powerful, need a cooldown on purchases[/spoiler]
-? Not much in terms of negative outcomes, only a handful that can really be called bad... granted, a few of them are [i]really[/i] bad.
-? Age gap... Depending on who you are and what you think of the setting, the age gap can be an issue for some romance paths (worst case is like 24 to 18, not outrageous but certainly questionable for modern standards).
+? Saves begin at the beginning of each turn only, essentially preventing save-scumming.
+? Japanese translation is decent, though that's coming from a non-native Japanese speaker.

Overall, I'd give this game a 9.5/10, with it very likely reaching 10/10 with updates to the localization and tooltips. Worth double its default price.  Get a copy for a friend who needs some wholesomeness in their life.

*Edit:  Added a couple more pros and cons for more clarity and some tips for new players.

141751868.review:
Summary: (9/10)
If you love “Long Live the Queen” game, or enjoy raising and caring for a child, this game may be for you. It is a visual novel based on a management simulation gameplay. The English translation is tolerable (especially after the early game) and the story is expansive and emotional. There are various characters to romance and interact at several places. And the artwork… so beautiful and so cute at times.

Story:
You follow the story of the father (you) and the daughter. You get the ability to customize the father and daughter’s name, and change the daughter’s outfits. Although viewing the game from the perspective of the father, at a certain point in the early game, the daughter is frequently able to travel alone without the father. Her interactions and adventures outside are within her perspective. Only at home or story events do you return to the father’s perspective.

There is a lot of lore to explore (the war, the spouse, the characters, etc) and you have about 40+ weeks to interact with the story and characters as much as possible. By the end of the game, you will understand what it feels like to be a father of a child. I never thought I would be so proud of a digital daughter.

Characters:
There are 16 romance-able and 2 non-romance-able characters. As you interact, gift, consult, challenge, or hangout with these characters, you will further develop a relationship with them. All of them have 3 unlock-able events with a cute cg artwork. Some are interesting, some cliché, and others are something else. 

Gameplay:
There is quite a bit of mechanics in play that must be covered so here is the simplified general overview.
The game will give you general goals to choose. For example, the kind of father you want to be (doting, strict, mentor, etc) and the progress toward said goals. As you play, the actions or choices you make may advance or hinder your progress to achieving said goal.

From character interactions, weekly class selections, party adventure, and more; there are a lot to do in the game. However, you do not need to go everywhere or do everything. I personally never unlocked the horse racing but still progressed easily. Just do as much or a little as you want to progress through the game.

The game is replay-able, especially if you want to see the 58 potential endings (with amazing cg art) that your daughter will grow up to be, see all three cg events of the interactable characters, or understand the lore behind the war and/or your spouse. It will, however, feel repetitive over time with some gameplay, especially with the weekly class selections.
The one game took about 10 hours for me, probably a few hours shorter if you avoid doing everything or understand the mechanics. 

The English translation, while clearly not the best, is quite do-able. I only really noticed significant translation errors in the early game, with the mid to late game occurring less. The errors themselves are not too difficult to understand the real meaning of the sentence. If grammar is such an issue for you, you may be daunted to play this game but I assured you that its worth the minor trouble to enjoy the game.

Price:
For $14 CDN, its set at a great price. This game became one of my most memorable games (give or take that most games nowadays are expensive for lacklustre gameplay), and with the numerous amounts of endings and replay-ability, it is worth every looney. 

Overall:
If the game pique your interest, purchase it. You always have 2 hours of gameplay before refunding anyway. This game was a renaissance for me as I never had any other similar game that I could compare to “Long Live the Queen.” Thanks to ShocTrooper for recommending the game to me.

141727321.review:
Volcano Princess is a chill, relaxing and very casual game in the vein of Princess Maker where you play the role of a parental figure and raise a young girl to adulthood. Has a lot of NPCs, most of which are romanceable by your daughter. NPCs are generally interesting and open up to you as you raise their favourability. As you play, locations are slowly added for you to explore. There's plenty of career paths for your daughter and events and locations. A few mini-games here and there (they're a bit of a mixed bag I guess).


Now for some negatives. First of all, there is absolutely zero challenge at all! The game is ridiculously easy, like game journalists would find it stupidly easy, that's how easy it is. There's no real stakes, your daughter cannot die, get sick and no real bad ending, etc. Also, even stumbling around on your first playthrough doing random stuff, it's far too easy to level up your stats to unlock the higher end career endings. This is before you start exploiting AP gains to do even more activities. Finishing achievements gives you points to make things even easier for new game+ as well. So if you're looking for a bit of challenge you will likely find yourself really disappointed.

FYI, I unlocked the 'true' ending on my first run, it's stupidly easy to complete. I went for a physical build and near the end of the game I got a prompt to follow my lord in fighting in the forest. So I did so, cleared the final forest level with the lord, then killed the couple of simple boss fights and boom true ending unlocked. Haven't played Princess Maker or some of it's other copycats but the general feel I got from them was that their 'true' endings generally were difficult to complete, requiring lots of exploring in other runs to learn more of secrets, not something everybody can stumble randomly into. I got the general gist of the ending but it was still a bit confusing given that this was my first run through the game. It made more sense after I did a run with the Princess as my lord and I finished this again along with the best career ending.

All the career and romance options make it sound like the game would be good for replayability but the game itself is really linear. Generally you'd want to just grind as many of these out by simply reloading last day save and choosing other career option. There's potions you can get that reduce your stats just for this reason lol. Romance can be swapped by keeping everybody below 140 and then just boosting the person you want with a date + gift.


FYI, game crashed when trying to catch a horse for the first time. This seems to be a known issue and resolved after restarting following the crash. Didn't notice any of bugs of note so overall game was stable for me. The English translation is very rough at times through but still good enough to follow the story. There's Chinese / Japanese voice acting (I've got no idea which one I had on, maybe Chinese)

141655423.review:
Ok, I didn't expect this one to suck me in so hard.

Volcano Princess is a raising sim, a life simulator/stat management game where you play as the single father to a young girl. With her mother missing, it is up to you to care and raise your daughter until she leaves the nest at the age of 18. During a playthrough you will decide which classes she takes, which jobs she works, who will she engage in a relationship with and so on. Depending on your choices your virtual daughter will choose a different career path at the end, and she could become everything from a simple waiter or actress to even a queen of the kingdom itself.

Like in all raising sims, the core gameplay loop of VP is raising your child's stats by interacting with people in a nearby town, enrolling her in classes, and managing her mood/stress level. You only have a limited number of actions you can spend each turn, and you have to think carefully where do you want to put your focus in. You can take part in various festivals, go on banquets, bet on horse races, grow crops on the field, go on expeditions to vanquish monsters in the wilderness, and even gamble through a dice mini-game.

In some ways VP is also kinda a dating sim. The Volcano Kingdom is populated with various people who your daughter can befriend and even romance. And yes, lesbian and even polyamorous relationships are very much possible, if someone wants to guide their daughter that way. It's heartwarming to see diverse love stories unfold, showcasing the developers' commitment to inclusivity and embracing different orientations and relationship dynamics. Each character has their own personality, backstory and preferred topics for conversations, and you can easily keep track of their relationship status with a handy and detailed menu screen. I feel there is something for everybody, from simple tavern girl and childhood friend, to inspired poet, and then a classic womanizer or a timid prince. All this is greatly enhanced by a charming art style. And before somebody asks: no, you can't marry your daughter.

VP has significant replay potential, with over 50 job endings you can earn, not to mention various romance options. For minmaxers, that want their daughter to become a wunderkind that is a world-class actress AND a crime boss AND a legendary warrior AND a prolific writer, there are numerous post-game bonuses. Earning achievements give you points that unlock huge advantages in future playthroughs such as stat boosting, additional dresses (for even more stat boosting) and even improved social status.

Volcano Princess is an ambitious indie title, and it still has a few bugs and exploits, but devs are actively patching them up. The English translation is pretty rough, and it often suffers from awkward phrasing, grammatical errors, and occasional inconsistencies, which can detract from the overall experience.

Despite this shortcoming, Volcano Princess remains a captivating daughter-raising simulator that offers hours of engaging gameplay. The game strikes a delicate balance between managing resources, fostering relationships, and exploring a rich world filled with intriguing characters. The narrative is filled with emotional moments, challenging decisions, and unexpected twists that keep players invested in their role as a caretaker.

This game enchanted me. I thought I would refund it, but then I spent 10+ hours utterly absorbed by my virtual daughters life, and then immediately starting a new game once the first had been finished. Whether you're a fan of simulation games or simply appreciate a heartfelt narrative, Volcano Princess is a journey worth embarking on.

Recommended

8+/10

141518087.review:
Recommended with some caveats: 

[list]
[*]The translation desperately needs work. I'm used to playing games with questionable translations, but in this case the poor translations get in the way of the being able to play the game. Character, item, and feature names are not consistent. Sometimes the story gets lost as I try to figure out what a sentence is supposed to mean rather than what it says. 
[*] The mini "games" are almost never games but just based on raw stats. If your stats are high enough, you win. If not, you lose. I wish there were an additional element of randomness to things like the debates and horse racing.
[*] Some of the achievements are broken or switched
[/list]

------

That aside, this is a fun social sim/life sim in the same vein as retro games like the Princess Maker series, [url = https://store.steampowered.com/app/736190/Chinese_Parents/]Chinese Parents[/url], and [url = https://store.steampowered.com/app/1191120/Growing_Up/] Growing up[/url. The art is top-notch, and there are a truly absurd number of endings. It's a great game to play when you don't want to think too hard about anything other than grinding stats. Overall, I would say it's worth the price, especially if you're already a fan of this type of sim or like visual novels and want something marginally more game-ified.

TL;DR: FUN, TIME-CONSUMING, LARGE RANGE OF ENDINGS AND ACTIVITIES... WILL ENJOY ESPECIALLY IF YOU'RE NARCISSISTIC... MONEY WELL SPENT CONSIDERING CRAZY AMOUNT OF PATHS YOU CAN FOLLOW 
A fun and eventful game about raising a daughter. The activities, character interactions and overall gameplay seem like a lot to deal with first, but eventually you learn to prioritise in order to reach your desired end goal. 141368268.review:
Even though the player assumes the role of Rose's father, you will be controlling Rose herself. In this way, the game forces you to put Rose's successes at the center of the game. She succeeds at nearly everything she does, because succeeding makes the game easier for you. Rose is designed to make you proud, just to put the panic in your heart when the game asks you: But yo dude, do you even make HER proud?

Rose's day will occasionally be disrupted with problems that you - that is, the father - need to talk her through. What you say to her determines how she sees you. If you neglect her, Rose will still go out and make you proud - but she will see you as terrible. For the most part though, it's hard to do wrong by Rose. Most folks grew up with parents who, even though they fumbled from time to time, loved them dearly. So long as you love your daughter, she will encourage you just as you encouraged her.

In a way, Volcano Princess feels like a celebration of parenthood and the bond that a father has with his daughter. Being a female gamer has its benefits for me here, too. Many of the choices I made reminded me of my own father and how proud he was at every little thing I did. It was a highly nostalgic and therapeutic game for me.

Games it reminds me of:
Love Live the Queen
Chinese Parents
Sunrider Academy
Princess Maker

Here are the minor issues I have with the game:
- Some meaning gets lost in translation. The "skip bonus" button after battle should read as "forfeit items", as an example.
- The text in duels and debates moves automatically and too quickly. I would have much preferred it if I had to click to advance the text in duels and debates.
- There's no option to fast forward through text. I recommend an auto-clicker program for anyone with hand/wrist pain, since you'll definitely want to replay the game a few times.

As an avid xianxia/wuxia web novel reader I absolutely love this game! I feel like you get so many choices to raise your daughter to become essentially anything which is nice since a lot of games have multiple endings but not as many as this game. She can be a concubine, a goddess, demon queen, or just straight up unemployed it all depends on how you raise her. There are probably 100+ endings and that isn't including the romantic type. You get to decide her love life and who she marries. One woman not enough for you? Marry two! Two guys not enough for you? Marry five! Maybe you want someone who makes YOU their main character in novels. Or that playboy that stops chasing women because he fell for you. This game has it all and so much more.

Are you a fan of Princess Maker? If you are, this game is dangerous for you because you will enjoy it way too much.

I'm a huge fan of the Princess Maker games, so I saw this game and went "oh God, I am doomed". And that's exactly what happened. "How are you putting 33hrs into a daughter-raising management game?" Honey, I still have one career ending and four more romance endings to get, I am not DONE

The art is SUPER cute, the game makes it easy for you to min-max stats and be able to change it up so you don't have to do like 50 runs (hint: the Strange Man at the docks will later unlock stat-reducing potions so you can get more of the endings that require lower stats!), and oh my god there are so many endings.

What also really helps is that like 95% of the career endings are NOT tied to the romance endings. There's like 3 or 4 career endings that have you not ending up with anyone for Reasons(tm). But I have gotten the most evil ending while still marrying the Princess. Its SO nice to be able to have the romance interests separate from the career endings.

The only slight con I have with this game is that the English translation is not the greatest. You can still understand the story and dialogue, so I was still invested in the True Ending when I got it. But there are moments where you have to stop and go "...oh THAT'S what they meant". Its not terrible, but it is noticeable

You will accidentally become a min-maxer and be too addicted to getting every endings but its okay because your daughter is so cute and you wanna do everything to make her happy. Until you start getting the endings associated with Darkness. Then sorry my love, but I need those endings.

Now if you'll excuse me, I need to get back to getting more endings. My daughter needs me.

This game is to Princess Maker what Stardew Valley is to Harvest Moon. It is a masterpiece and well worth the money but marred by simple issues the devs seemingly have no interest in fixing.

Be warned that all magic items gotten from monster drops are useless and only meant to be sold. Presumably the devs had a crafting system planned at some point, scrapped it, but didn't bother to provide any other use for the drops.

This is clear as some of the monster drops look like components of some of the higher tier decorations, accessories, and weapons. One decoration even shares a name with the feather dropped from one of the monsters.

Be aware that the game will crash once when you first open the menu to catch Horses for every single player. (So make sure that's the first thing you do on that day so you don't lose progress) I'm told that this is a documented and long-standing bug that affects all players, but the devs haven't bothered to fix it or warn people on the Store page or in the game menu.

I'm going to thumbs down this game until this is addressed so at least someone may be saved from the same experience as I lost an entire days progress due to this easily avoidable situation.

141139906.review:
[i]I wish this dad was real[/i]


I honestly started this game as a joke. I saw it multiple times on steam and always ignored it because from the images it didn't tell me much. But then I decided to try it, and boy if I regret not playing it earlier...
The images literally transmit NOTHING of the whole essence of the game.

I wasn't really expecting much from the start, nonchalantly opening it and putting my friend's name as my Daugher's name for some laugh, then the game hits you with "What kind of Father do you want to be?", giving you three choices.
From those three choices you understand that there's way more in this game than just a cute chilly game with cute arts.
It's a whole constructed RPG.
There's everything: fighting, duels, entertainment, games with dices, race with horses, taming, relationships, bonds, houses (as in royalty, or take Harry Potter), customization both of clothes and the room, routes, skill trees, the "darkness" ([i]when you walk away[/i], literally), multiple endings and secret endings (that's what the game tells you about the darkness).
It's so damn full of stuff that I really was. not. expecting at all.

Like I said I started this game as a joke, it was around 11pm, after a bit of playing, without noticing it was already 3am. "A little bit more and then I'll go to sleep"; two hours later at 5am+ my homie reaching for me "Please go to sleep"
"Soon™".

The first playthrough is gonna be a bit confusing, for me at least it was. Might it be the late hours or the overload of some informations, but I didn't understand some things at first, and I've failed the father's goal TWICE, but it's fine because the replayability of this game is definitely high and I'm gonna go for it again; like I said there's multiple endings and routes and decisions to take, and it doesn't seem like doable doing both the fighter and the royalty route together for obvious reasons.

The story of the game may seems pretty blant at first but I think it's deeper than what it feels like. Playing the role of the Father and watching your Daughter growing, learning how life can be harsh; in fact almost everytime you're doing something for the first time, you're going to fail. You're sad about that, but that's just life, and in the end, just like the Daughter do, think about the food and move on, because it's going to get better and you're gonna improve. This is definitely what this game shows and it does it pretty well. 
There's more in the whole story itself but I still don't know because I'm writing my first impression after my first ending, but there is and it does sound interesting.
The OSTs are good, very comfy and chill. The art is really cute and good at the same time.

I feel like this game will receive many more patch notes; I've seen people saying the english translation is bad, and sometimes it is indeed a bit strange. But they're definitely improving it because it doesn't sound as bad as people make it sound.

In the end I would say this game it's definitely worth its price, if you see it and you're not convinced by it from the images on steam (like I was), try it. If you're scared you can always refund it and two hours are enough to understand if you like it or not; if you notice them go by.

This game has scratched and itch I've been having since Cute Knight Kingdom when I was just an itty bitty gamer. Other games have sort of touched on it, but this is so open that it's addictive. 

There are a ton of different endings for different stat levels, and a ton of different romances. This could be a good or bad thing depending on your play style, but I personally love the replayability and to be able to connect the dots myself. 

The translations aren't completely clear in some places, and you have to adjust to English the first time you boot up the game, but it's clear enough to understand. Some of the nuanced ideas and metaphors don't translate well, which lead to some confusion about the "true" ending, but there's forum discussions to help out with that. I think some stuff was meant to be open to interpretation, but that may be my optimism and love for these kinds of games. 

10/10 would be doting father to over powered knight again.

141033189.review:
The game is great and while I do recommend it, there are a few issues that I would like to address.

[hr][/hr]

1. Grammar. (In English at least)
The grammar could use some work which is understandable since the game is originally Chinese. The names of the characters are inconsistent and changes from time to time in the story and even in the achievements which leads to confusion. Most of these are negligible and very minor but you'll have to connect the dots yourself sometimes.


[hr][/hr]
[h1]Possible spoilers below[/h1]
[hr][/hr]


2. Endings/Achievements*
My biggest gripe of the game as of writing this review. The way this game checks for some endings (and some achievements) is via tiers which means that you'll some endings have that have 2 or more versions of that ending and whichever the highest tier depending of its conditions is the ONLY ending you can select. Heres a very simplified example of what.

[table]
[tr][th]Ending[/th][th]Requirement[/th][/tr]
[tr][td]Scholar[/td][td]MND > 50[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Great Scholar[/td][td]MND > 100[/td][/tr]
[/table]

Here you can see 2 endings split in 2 different tier and this is where the problem starts. If by the end of the game lets say your MND is around 120, that would mean that you will unlock the Great Scholar ending and [b]ONLY[/b] the Great Scholar ending so even if you technically cleared the requirements for the lower tier ending, it will not be unlocked unless you play the game again from the start and [b]PURPOSELY[/b] limit your characters abilities. Leading to multiple "speedrun"s of the game just to unlock an ending.

As much as I like the game, I dont have it in me to play extra fast multiple times just to unlock endings and I hope we get to have a patch in the future to just unlock all tiers of endings as a choice if we did meet its criteria. Overall though, my enjoyment if the game is still good and I highly recommend it.

140967446.review:
I really like this game and would recommend it... [u][b]if[/b][/u] it wasn't for a few major problems with the game. As soon as these are fixed I can confidently give it my seal of approval. I would still recommend it if you can snag it on a good steam-sale deal

1.
Currently the English translation is riddled grammatical mistakes and other problems such as;
-Spelling errors 
-Capitalization problems
-Incorrect Syntaxing
-Weird/stiff sounding English or "Chinese word for word translations" occasionally
              -This causes some NPC dialogue, which I assume in Chinese would characterize the NPC's better, to feel very samey
-The tutorial text and "system mechanic" names are written in really bizarre English.

2. 
There are a surprisingly large amount of bugs for what is a glorified visual novel. Some of these will freeze your game forcing you to close the application and start the day over and some causes text dialogue to skip at seemingly random

Beyond these 2 massive problems that keep me from recommending this game I do have a fair bit of other criticisms just the same way I have things that I would praise the game for.

[u]Cons:[/u] 
0. All of the bugs/English translation problems that I noted above.
1. The gameplay gets very stale very quickly because of it's repetitive nature. The game tries to remedy this by giving the players minigames and access to an turn-based RPG combat area but it does not in anyway push you towards that with a very few exceptions.
2. The soundtrack is fairly poor and the Audio mixing is none existent. At best it's a atmospheric piece that gets abruptly cut off because you left the area. At worst it's a very recognizable copyright free ost that clearly stands out and does not fit the vibe of the area at all.
3. You will need to discover most of the game by yourself. It gives occasional tutorials but they're written in bizarre English and are mostly front-loaded when you start playing the game. It can be a struggle to find the tutorials after you've clicked past them.
You could argue that the last point is kind of fitting as it's a game about growing up and having to find your own way in this world

[u]Pros:[/u] 
1. A very wholesome and comfy story about growing up. At times the characters can seem a bit unrealistic for their age in terms of how they act but that's a minor nitpick on my end.
2. Overall very good looking artwork.
3. A lot of endings with a build in newgame+ to speed things up..
4. The game does not lock your daughter into just dating "canonical characters" as many games use as an excuse. If they're an NPC that you can build rapport with, they're romanceable.

140953890.review:
For some reason while playing this I was getting this strong feeling of nostalgia that I couldn't figure out where it was coming from.. until I really thought about it, it reminds me of a really old android game I was obsessed with when I was like 12, some of the music is even the same, and its the same concept and the game-play is pretty much the same. 

Essentially you play as a father raising his daughter and helping her to grow into a young lady. There are many different characters you can befriend or marry, this game allows you to marry both men and women and if you want you can have a romantic ending with 2 people at the same time! 

Like any other game you have skills you should raise to get the outcome you want, depending on what skill you focus on you get a different career endings, and some romantic endings. Unlike other games you choose the ending, meaning it gives you multiple options in the end if you focused on multiple skills or if that skill has multiple careers tied to it. It also tells you what skills you have to upgrade to get closer to the NPCs instead of just leaving you to figure it out yourself.

The only cons to this game is the bad grammar and/or chopping sentences. This game is very Dialog heavy and has a story you can follow, while it was slightly difficult to understand what they were saying initially I managed to understand if I thought about it for a second. So maybe don't play of you're just going to skip all the dialog as it makes up most the game-play. 

What I really liked about this game is that its easy to befriend the NPCs, say you talked to them once every month, if you do that literally every month in the end you will have befriended them, of course it would take some more effort to romance them but you would be more than halfway there at that point. 

p.s: make sure you know your math :') this game will randomly quiz you at random times

140952244.review: I teared up watching my daughter graduate

140949913.review:
Yet another gem that I've uncovered in the depths of my own mind. This year I've gone with a different take on gaming by mixing up the genres and its been surprisingly fruitful so far. 

This game is full of secrets, joy and well impact, every single decision counts which isn't surprising at all given what this game is about. Although I played this game from from start to finish in one sitting, I didn't regret any bit of it, except the headache which is coming on now, but reviews are best written while the game is still fresh in your memory. Still there are a few things that will unfortunately drag the score down,  let me  explain in a bit.

Story: 10/10 
Art/Graphics: 10/10 
Gameplay: 6.5/10 
Soundtrack: 6.5/10 
Translation for ENG: 5/10 
Replayability: Yup
Overall score: 7/10

Reasons for the scores:

* Story: Multiple choices and multiple endings
* Art/Graphics: Very cute, its anime no surprise there
* Gameplay: Due to translation issues/bugs, my score would randomly drop when it shouldn't have and vice versa, accordingly if you did well by the scores, the dialogue would say you did poorly and the other way around. Hardly any tutorials - you'd get randomly thrown in many of the events and by the time you figure out what to do you've lost action points and gold
Soundtrack: Ambient audio doesn't fit with the setting e.g. sirens can be heard in the background and its very repetitive
* English translation: C for effort, but there are a lot of words with grammar issues, random spaces, some sentences are all lowercase. You eventually get used to it, but it harms immersion. I could fix the issues for free, don't have much to do anyways
* Bugs: Quite a few, but might just be me, I'll do a NG+ run and re-check. Autosave and manual save do the same thing, which is putting you back at the start of the month, not where you left off


Overall, I give it a score of 7 with the hope that future patches will fix any translation issues.

140917649.review:
The greatest, most polished princess maker clone out there.
Gorgeous art, sweet characters, yuri is real, and best of all the systems actually work together! So many smart moves were made using the stat building system both in and out of schedule, it ensures that your time is never wasted and that your planning actually matters. No need to fight RNG here. A knight, painter, scholar or demon queen-- No matter what you choose, you're going to have a good time. I also appreciate how you can actually roleplay as a father in this one: your input gives stat boosts as well as truly emotional moments that make you more connected to your daughter.
My only critique is the translation. Clearly it was an MTL job which is a shame 'cos it butchers a few emotional moments. It's not completely indecipherable, but an actual human translation would've been much better.
Yep,  by far the best princess maker-like on the market. Throw all your money at it, your daughter needs you!

140601712.review:
I wasn't convinced to purchase the game before, so i waited for discount.
After several playthroughs, oh boy this is a gem.
It is like the Princess Maker 2 or 3, but even better.
More QoL, better progression, like it has shorter little-kid period to access to the latter options faster. The art is cute, the chibi are cute.
If anything lack is probably the lewd aspect of the Princess Maker (they had more revealing outfit). But i'm not complaining, outfits in this game are top notch design wise.
My complaint is, i feel this could be expanded further...
Perhaps at later DLC.
The child's job for example, is a bit lacking compared to PM.
No church job, work at home options (housekeeping, stable keeping for example).
Also more dungeon variety, other than the forest and the dark alley.
More costume, i liked the gears at the ending.
Full plate armor, Hunter outfit, etc.
Or even go to r18 if you want to be thorough with some of the endings.

For who don't understand Princess Maker.
It is a kid raising game. From a little 8-10 y/o kid to 17 or 18th.
Doing actions will increase or decrease the kid's stat. The actions are such, taking a lesson, doing work, battling monsters, fishing, farming, painting, participating contests, festival, etc. How you manage your daughter will trigger a specific ending. You might be a doting father, caring father, etc. Also it will decide with whom she will marry later. It is quite an arduous process, especially at the original Princess Maker. And the ending is supposedly the fruition of your hard work. It is a management game with RPG element, have multiple story, and ending. Collecting the harder ending is also why it has a lot of replay-ability value.

Do i recommend the game? Oh yes. A big yes.
This game has a lot of content for the price.
A huge replay-ability to complete its multiple ending. And each playtrough may weave a different story.
My previous complaint was because the ending outfits are such a masterpiece, and more content is a big welcome.
Princess Maker only limit the playing time frame until the daughter 17 or 18 y/o, maybe Egg hatcher could break the tradition?

140434561.review:
Este juego me tiene enganchado.

Similar a Princess Maker pero mucho mas accesible, se nota que las creadoras tienen experiencia jugando este tipo de juegos y saben que partes suelen hacerse mas molestas para el jugador. Hay menos estadísticas que tomar en cuenta y son relativamente fáciles de manejar, lo que evita quebraderos de cabeza cuando estas buscando un final especifico. Ademas, la mayoría de los finales (que por cierto son bastantes) son relativamente fáciles de alcanzar en los 40 turnos que nos dan, evitando que un ciclo se acabe sintiéndose demasiado largo (problema que tuve con, por ejemplo, Ciel Fledge). Incluso los finales mas complicados pueden volverse muy fáciles si optas por aplicar las bonificaciones de NG+, por no hablar de que  puedes obtener fácilmente 8-10 finales en cada ciclo, ya que no te encierran en uno en particular en base a tus estadísticas (e incluso te marcan los que ya has conseguido antes, ademas de permitirte reducir tus estadísticas para sacar versiones inferiores del mismo tipo de final)

Ademas de la habitual pantalla de distribución del tiempo para cada mes también tienes el control de la hija durante su día a día, que supone buena parte del ciclo de juego. Este aspecto me pareció genial al añadirle una dimensión mas a la experiencia mas típica, completamente enfocada en el punto de vista del tutor/a.

La OST es otro aspecto que me gusto. Junto con el arte en general contribuye mucho a generar un ambiente acogedor pero misterioso.

Lo único que veo criticable es que la traducción al ingles es inconsistente a veces y puede perjudicar la experiencia. También se agradecería que, tal y como hacen con los finales de profesión, permitieran elegir un final romántico pues es algo molesto que los finales de grupo se superpongan con los individuales.

140250597.review:
Volcano Princess is a very simple game with a very simple premise, but I've been enjoying it immensely. The music, art, and atmosphere are sweet, beautiful, and relaxing. The side games have good mechanics and allow you to really be a part of most of her actions. The characters are very likable, the courses to study all make sense and give worthwhile benefits, and the mysteries are intriguing and the choices are truly varied.

My only real complaint is that it feels like the time goes too fast. We keep checking back in every month even though we only choose courses for a week. I understand much of this is for balancing, but with how the system is set up, any courses you can't complete in four classes aren't worth pursuing at all and any books that can be accomplished in a day trumps the regular curriculum. I can understand wanting to make sure the player doesn't do too much, but there's enough course options I think the chance to have more time there, like choosing the courses week by week then only getting the days with the daughter every month as it is currently, would improve the experience, allowing more of a chance to round out the daughter or to utterly focus on all the courses in their main area of expertise.

140237863.review:
I really like Princess Maker, so when I saw this I decided to give it a try. I have to say, I am not disappointed at all! The characters are fun, the story is interesting, and the game is way more interactive with Princess Maker, with us being able to walk around as the daughter and being able to work, go on adventures and hang out with and make friends all independently of the schedule function, whereas in Princess Maker you had to fit exploration, schooling, hanging out and working in the schedule and so it was a real pick-and-choose struggle. The art is also really great, and I highly encourage people to play it! 

Also, there's achievements you can get, so there's GREAT replay value. Another thing to note, this is actually YOUR kid. It's not a kid that you got gifted in a field one day or found somewhere, this is your own kid. And that's just so beautiful to me.

140223154.review: The Volcano Princess truly shines in terms of replay value. 139707705.review:
Really engaging little game with shitloads of content, over 58 endings with unique, high quality CGs. Bear in mind you can get multiple per playthrough, the game encourages reloading the last save to see the different endings you met the criteria for so it's not like you need to do the full 8-9 hours to beat it for every ending.

Gameplay's a lot of fun, has lot of mini games (a turned based rpg, horse racing, a dice game, dating sim to name a few) but they all work fine and it's all well structured around building stats and making smart choices. Best compliment I can give is the sheer effort on display - so many little bits and pieces that really show the devs poured their hearts into the project.

If I had a main criticism though, it's the English translation. I appreciate that the devs are based in Beijing and it doesn't seem like China has the best access to translators but it is really noticeably stiff at times, to the point I wonder if they just used an AI or something to run over the script. That being said though it is perfectly readable, just some awkward lines. The other text translations are Simplified Chinese and I think Japanese (sorry I'm quite bad at discerning other languages, steam only lists Chinese and English so might be wrong) and from what I understand those are way better.

Ultimately a game I'd highly recommend, really want to see more from the developers because the talent on display is staggering.
