139657166.review:
For those who don't wanna read the paragraph, TLDR; Good wholesome daughter raising sim that's no where near as creepy as the Princess maker series can get.

The art for the game is everywhere, and gorgeous. No matter what you're doing, they have specific art for it. Cooking? small animation, each class subject has it's own art too. Without spoiling too much, every one of the numerous endings has their own CG and dialogue to truly show how she's faring.

The game play is nice and simple, you as a dad manage what classes your daughter takes, and what she does until she grows old enough and ascertains her own autonomy. When she gets there, you control her instead but the dialogue and stuff still talks about you being the dad and all. These activities give you stats which will be instrumental in helping get any ending

When it comes to getting those aforementioned endings, volcano princess makes the trips to these endings much easier and you'll need it since you aren't accomplishing s**t on your first playthrough. It's not an insult, its a fact but eventually you'll get the good endings. 

No game is without flaw, thankfully there aren't too many. The translation is still bad, but no where near as bad as before this last update. Now you can understand what every character is getting at when they're speaking rather than disjointed thoughts you have to scrape together.

Now that i know what every character is actually saying, without spoiling anything once again, they're all mostly unique. I can't say i found any of them outright annoying, and each of the associated events are quite sweet, with even the edgier characters having nice wholesome moments (mostly).

Being able to skip dialogue with CTRL is a godsend after your first couple loops. If you want to see most of this game, one go around will be no-where near enough giving the game immense replayability.

Now I know i'm a stranger, but i'm handing out unsolicited advice and you can't stop yourself from reading this review now anyway.
If you do decide to play this game, Go in as blind as possible. Don't worry too much about any of the stats, what ending you may get, or whatever. The wiki can and should wait. Just focus on being a parent first. Cherish that time as a parent watching her grow up and remain blissfully ignorant of the inevitable numbers game to get the cool endings.

139349038.review:
For some unknown reason... I seem to have gained an itch for doting father-raising-daughter content. And this game scratched it perfectly.

I was not sure whether I should buy this game considering people were talking about translation errors and some bugs, as well as there being a lot to micromanage, but honestly the management is super easy and explained well and the rest don't ruin the experience enough to make me say "don't buy it". I only encountered maybe 2 bugs/crashes through my entire game, and most of the time if there is a less than amazing translation you can usually figure out what it means.

My first play through took about 12 or so hours and I was smiling like a damn idiot the whole way through. I also did a lot of useless and random stuff which might've made my play time longer and while there is a wiki that is pretty bare-bones as I am writing this most things are easy enough to understand and even an idiot like me got the true ending on my first run. Another great part about this game is that unlike the usually empty void in my heart I feel when I complete a game, I actually felt incredibly happy to see my daughter become a functioning person. It made me feel so damn proud, so much so that I wrote this review.

This game is great, and now having the bonuses unlocked it makes me even more inclined to play again, though I'll be damned if you get me to do any of the vile endings, they may be achievements but you will not tempt me.

The gameplay: Is very simple yet still has depth to it with management. Interacting with other people in the world and befriending them by talking, gifting and going on friendly dates with them. Each character has there own story and are fleshed out very well. There are horse riding events to do, Theatre, Bathhouse and a dice mini game. There is a dungeon/adventure part of the game that involves combat which has a bit of strategy involved to survive and get the best rewards/fame. There is kind of a NG+ feature once you complete it for the 1st time. So when starting a new game (fresh run) you can boost some of your stats for that run.

The Graphics: The artstyle is very beautiful and well coloured. Lots of CG's to unlock and view (Once you complete the game once) Not many animated scenes but not really necessary imo. 

Verdict: This game was quite amazing. Nice slice of life sim that will put a smile on your face. 19 hours for my 1st playthrough and looking forward to starting another for more achievements. At full price (It's not that expensive anyways) it's so worth it <3

139060507.review:
I was expecting this to be another run of the mill daughter raising/princess maker game, but man, was I wrong. It's one of the best of the genre I've played so far! I wouldn't say that it does anything particularly special, but it just does everything right. Sometimes getting all the basics of the game smooth and polished all you need to make a fantastic game.
The game loop is a fair length, about 7 hours per run (and longer for your first go of course), but it's somehow not tedious. I've only played it through about 6 times and I haven't even discovered everything that the game has to offer yet. I personally don't really like the minigames, but it doesn't take away from the main mechanics of the game. The stat system sits somewhere between unforgivably challenging and easy, which is part of why it didn't feel tedious.
There are quite a few characters, and they are lovely to talk with. Even with the idle chatter, they don't repeat dialogue, which is honestly incredible. Amazing job by the game's writers! Each character is also really unique, well developed, and ties beautifully within Volcano. It's selfish of me but I do wish there were more special romance scenes per character, because there are only three per character, and I want to know more about them! I was surprised on two counts, firstly that you could 'romance' pretty much every character, and secondly that there were even polyamory options. I haven't tried the poly options yet, but man it's nice to see they're there!
Art was flawless, your daughter always looks adorable no matter which outfit you pick! There are so many beautifully drawn little scenes in the game too, it really was a feast for the eyes.
A definitely must play if you're a fan of the genre, it's just done too well to miss out on it! The price is more than fair if you're really going to go collect all the endings, which definitely will take you a hundred hours or more. Heck, it's fair even if you're only going to play through once!

138793857.review:
Volcano Princess is pretty much Princess Maker except super Chinese. But, unlike normal Chinese parenting which is about trapping your child in a pain box and forcing the to learn the piano by the age of four, this is more of a visual novel where you raise your virtual daughter in arguably the most easy simulation game I have ever seen.

So, let's start with the good and the bad.

The Good:
1. It's super cute. Like insanely cute. The NPCs are all charming enough and the writing makes you want to say "awwhhhh" while force feeding your dog taco bell. I mean, it's so absurdly adorable that it almost makes me feel sick in some kinda strange gut feel.

2. There is like a million different endings and all of them are pretty entertaining.

3. It has enough variety in day to day activities to not get boring.

The Bad:
1. It's far too easy. Like, absurdly easy. You will power max each stat with ease on your first play. It'a almost impressive how much hand holding the game has with action point recovery which is the resource used for the limited actions you have in each day in game.

2. The Combat system is really dumb. I mean, once again, it's easy, but it's very boring. 

3. Translation. There is various little translation errors and while I don't blame Chinese dev's for having these issues, there is a few times in game where you will just be baffled by the translation job and it's meager attempts to keep everything inline. 

4. The devs I believe have been trying to figure out the steam cloud save options for like six months now and are still trying to battle it, which, while funny, seems kind of odd. 

So, is Volcano Princess good? Yeah, it's a fun game. I got my money and feels out of it. But it def could use a bit of spice and perhaps far more difficulty.

All the things I like about the Princess Maker series without the annoyances I have with a lot of them. 

Major bonuses:
You can carry over your efforts between playthroughs, making it easier to try for specific endings.

Romance and Job/Adventure/Story endings are separate- you're not locking yourself out of a specific job ending if you want to marry the prince, for instance. You can have both!

I also wish there was a brief blurb about each of the blood types in the game- I had to go to wikipedia to see what each one meant. 

great raising sim, over all.

138548079.review:
Volcano Princess is another child-raising game in the vein of Princess Maker, Long Live the Queen, Chinese Parents, and Growing Up. It does have very nice artwork, a slick presentation, a narrative story (!) and already a lot of replay value possible. 

However, [b]I can only give the game a lukewarm recommendation[/b] for one glaring reason: [b]the English translations and localisations are fairly poor.[/b]

I've played Chinese Parents which is in the same genre, and it also suffers from poor translation and localisation, but I think it feels worse in Volcano Princess for one glaring reason: [b] the English translation/localisation is the only thing holding this game back from being absolutely outstanding[/b]!

There is so much content under the hood here for this niche genre, and most impressively, the game does a nice job in the early days of giving you a tutorial of the nature of stat management and how to invest your time as you go.  Some games in this genre offer little to no guidance, so Volcano Princess does that remarkably well. Also, there is a legitimate plot and story arc going on here that is meatier than the generalities of lore you might see in Princess Maker 2.  I really love that. 

The content, visuals, and gameplay loop are all here, frankly. But with the amount of content and character dialogue there is for building relationships, and other scenes that revolve around it, language is a lot more important to the enjoyment of the game.  And with the jarring translation and localisation choices peppered throughout in dialogue, menus, and tips, it really lets the game down and affects my enjoyment of it.

I understand the game has likely been made by a small team, and may not have had much in the way of resource to dedicate to English translation and localisation.  But God, if they could improve it, I'd recommend the game to all of my friends who enjoy VNs and simulation games. Until that happens, I can only barely recommend it.

138435941.review:
This is my first time playing a game like this, and for a beginner like me, it was enjoyable despite figuring out what to do or how certain mini-games & other functionality can be stressful. The game focused more on grinding and very much strategy-based, and the strategy part also differs in terms of what goal/ending you are working to get by the end of it.

Some of the issues that is a bit off-putting for me is just the translation in terms of the characters' name and the dialogues. As someone who doesn't speak English as their first language, it is understandable, however I do hope this will be improved in the future. However, some of the inconsistent spacing between words in the English version is jarring which often happens when you translate the writings into this language, but I'm sure this will be fixed in future updates. The energy bar is small and a bit limited since certain actions can cost you around 5-8 points, which means it is depleted quite fast unless you've prepared beforehand, but that adds to the challenging nature of this game which can be a selling point to other players. Some of the mini-games' instructions are a little unclear which are partly due to the translation issue, and partly due to myself for not connecting the dots. There are some bugs that you might accidentally find, but from my experience after encountering one and submitting a report, the developers are proactive in solving them although it might take some time.

As this is my first time playing a game within this genre, I'm not able to provide an in-depth comment on the plot except that I did enjoy the story line. The art style is cute. I love that you have a lot of options when it comes to love interests and even other relationships, who each have an interesting story to tell. I like that I can restart the day if I messed up on certain activities, which is very forgiving of the game. As another person commented, despite being the father, it does feel like the story doesn't push the daughter to the side and give her the autonomy in most of the actions performed in the game as the story revolves around her life. The playthroughs that come after you've completed the first one feel easier once you familiarized yourself with it.

Overall, would I recommend it? Yes, if you can overlook the problems I mentioned and allow the developers some time to solve it. I'd say it is a nice introductory game for beginners!

138323630.review:
I really loved this game! 

There are tons of systems which on their own have just enough depth to make them interesting, but the breadth of things to occupy your (daughter's) days with is really fun. Each little activity has a small learning curve before you can figure out how to maximize your success: admittedly none of the activities seem very well balanced or super polished, so once you figure out the optimal strategy there is not much to think about within the activity itself. You really have tons of freedom though with which parts of the game to engage with and come up with a palette of activities you want to focus on. The main choice is always where you want to spend your time, and it really just feels like a bonus that each system is deep enough to be somewhat interesting. Unfortunately it seems like there were some systems which got cut, and some items which don't really have a use... a shame that it could have been even better. 

Based on the positive reviews I expected the life sim gameplay to be good, but what surprised me was the strength of the story and characters. It's not a masterpiece, but there is definitely some intrigue and emotional weight to the events of the 
story as the years progress. There are some cute events with the named characters, and all but a couple of them I found pretty interesting after seeing a couple of their events and getting to know them. Re: the english translation... it isn't perfect, for 95% of the game it's serviceable and you'll be able to understand what characters are saying just fine. The other 5% is mostly just small errors like characters having different romanized names (e.g. rebessa instead of lebsa) and only a few times I wasn't fully sure what was being said. I was surprised by how good the translation seemed to be in other instances though, some of the characters spoke pretty eloquently.

Overall too cute for its own good and lots of crunchy systems to sink your teeth into!

138204636.review:
Volcano Princess is a captivating and heartwarming game that takes players on a unique journey of parenthood within the enchanting world of the Volcano Kingdom. As the main character, you step into the shoes of a grieving parent, tasked with raising your daughter and providing her with a fulfilling life.

The game beautifully blends elements of life simulation and exploration, allowing players to immerse themselves in the vibrant world of the Volcano Kingdom. The visuals are charming and evoke a sense of wonder, with lush landscapes and delightful character designs that bring the kingdom to life.

One of the standout features of Volcano Princess is the emphasis on the parent-child relationship. As the sole guardian of your daughter, you have the responsibility of shaping her future through your choices and interactions. The game brilliantly captures the joys and challenges of parenthood, as you navigate various aspects of her life, including her daily routines, studies, and extracurricular activities.

The depth of gameplay is impressive, as you engage in a wide range of hobbies and interests with your daughter. From exploring new areas of the kingdom to trying out different jobs, the game offers a diverse set of activities that keep the experience engaging and fresh. This variety allows players to discover the talents and passions of their daughter, helping her grow and flourish as an individual.

The narrative of Volcano Princess is both heartwarming and emotionally resonant. It delicately explores themes of loss, family bonds, and the power of love. The game presents players with meaningful choices that impact the relationship between the main character and their daughter, emphasizing the importance of fostering a strong and nurturing connection.

In addition to its compelling story, Volcano Princess also excels in its attention to detail and world-building. The Volcano Kingdom feels like a living, breathing place, filled with charming NPCs, captivating lore, and intriguing secrets waiting to be uncovered. The soundtrack complements the gameplay perfectly, immersing players in the magical atmosphere of the kingdom.

While the game focuses primarily on the parent-child relationship, it also provides opportunities for personal growth and self-discovery for the main character. As you guide your daughter through life's challenges, you too will find yourself growing and learning valuable lessons along the way.

Overall, Volcano Princess is a touching and heartfelt experience that will resonate with players of all ages. Its captivating world, engaging gameplay, and meaningful themes make it a standout title in the genre of life simulation games. Whether you're a fan of parenthood-themed games or simply seeking a charming and emotionally rich experience, Volcano Princess is a must-play game that will leave a lasting impression.

Rating: 9/10

138192557.review:
In this game you have to raise your daughter in a fantasy, middle age world. You will encounter the difficulties, and the joy of raising a child. You can guide your daughter on her journey until she reaches the age of 18. This game is made to be played more than once, with countless endings. And in the end, the game will always decide, whether you have grown up to your own expectations or not. 

In short, its a wonderful game about parenting.

138183776.review:
TLDR: 10/10 recommend for anyone who loves multiple endings and raising sims. Worth every penny.

I've been playing this game almost non stop since release. I bought it for myself for my birthday as I love daughter/princess raising sims. I was pleasantly surprised at just how much content is in this game for the price!! The art style, all the endings and achievements possible, the backstories and all the mini-games make this an absolute steal.

In the beginning there were a few bugs that were frustrating however I expected such as a brand new game and the developers have been releasing updates in a very timely manner. Some of the translations are a little off as you can tell it wasn't English based but nothing I can't understand or look over.

I'll be sad when I've completed all the achievements and have no reason to play anymore.. looking forward to future games like this if they come out with any more!!

138179819.review:
[h1]A kingdom for my Rose[/h1]

Let us get this right out of the way at the start: Volcano Princess is a brilliant game and everyone who has even a small interest in the game after watching the trailer or reading the synopsis should definitely buy it. The price is completely fair for the amount of content you get.

Now to put into words why this game is so good.

[b][u]Presentation[/u][/b]
This game is drop dead gorgeous for its niche. The artstyle is reminiscent of Chinese web comics first and foremost and really good ones at that. There are an unusual amount of CGs in this game. From ending professions and romance options, to story scenes or even minor interactions, the art is everywhere. A lot of raising sims mostly rely on text or numbers, but Volcano Princess goes the extra mile to visualize almost everything. 
Even the inventory items and monster designs are all lovingly made with details that immerse you even more. Every location is very distinct and even one off events like tournaments get special screens.

The only area where the game is slightly hindered is when it comes to animations. They are generally a bit clunky or unexpressive, but that too has its charme. These usually only happen during activities and are more like small gifs. Generally the art is static.

[b][u]Gameplay[/u][/b]
The basic gameplay loop is simple. You are tasked with raising your daughter by advising her and deciding what she will study at the academy. Unlike a lot of raisintg sims however, you spent a considerable amount of time every day from the daughter's point of view and make those decisions through her. So it is not that the father molds his daughter like a puppet, but rather that the player takes both the role of the father and the daughter.

As expected from this genre, most of your focus will be on raising stats or gaining favor with people. Gathering items, receiving gits and better lectures are all means to getting one of the over 50 professions the game has to offer, alongside figuring out your potential marriage partner(s). The game offers an unprecedented amount of choices and variables for this and if you don't want to work at all or if you dislike romance you can even avoid both of those things altogether.

What stands out most is just the sheer variety of activities the game offers. I spent my entire first playthrough completely ignoring the horse catching/raising game and never participated in races. But those are fully fleshed out mechanics that you can focus an entire playthrough around to get fame and money. You can go explore dungeons with friends, you can go to banquets and get acqauinted with nobles, you can study all day, you can go fishing, you can do alchemy, duel other characters in battle or debates, work as an actress or in a bathouse... and so so so much more.

Your academic/knight tasks depend mostly on what house you picked when you enrolled and who your Lord/Lady is. You can pick one of three and the head of each faction is only available for interaction when you pick theirs, so certain romance options or quests are only available depending on the current faction.

The daily loop I think most will go through is this: Father/daughter interactions --> farming at the field to get items --> raising your stats and interacting with characters and activities --> decide on that month's curriculum at the academy.
The game has around 40 turns (which each represent one month) and once your daughter is 18 years old and becomes and adult the game ends.

[b][u]Romance[/u][/b]
The game features a large and lovable cast of characters. Not all of them are love interests, but the majority are. Your daughter (whose default name is Rose, so I will call her that usually) is bisexual and can marry both men and women. The choices are exceptionally varied. You can let Rose romance her classmates, her Lords/Ladies, royalty, the inn keeper, a nun, artists, a lone wolf mercenary and many more.
The method to get those romance endings is basically to hang out with the characters you like and get their affection to the right level and see their events. Some endings or paths will lead to not having certain options available, but do not be discouraged, that love can bloom in another playthrough.

This game really has a endearing cast in general, but I think some of my favorite characters are princess Gwyneth, her brother Kenneth (you can get a polyamorous ending with both of them as your lovers btw), the best friend Nina and the author Lon.
Whether you prefer straight romance, lesbian romance or something inbetween, the game has it all and is not judgemental in any way. Two women can marry without issue and are just as valid as any other option. The age gap between Rose and some of these characters is rather large admittedly, but that's the great thing, you don't have to do anything you dislike.

I generally prefer yuri/sapphic romance, so I was quite pleased with the plentiful of female love interests, but the game presents all its characters so charmingly that I didn't mind getting Rose close to the boys as well. Due to the nature of the game encouraging replays it is fine to experiment more in my opinion.

My only gripe right now is that one romance partner is very questionable... for story related reasons. And yes there is a story!

[b][u]Story[/u][/b]
While the overall goal is simply for the daughter to grow into a great adult, there is a lot more going on with the Volcano Kingdom. It has a lot of well integrated lore that you uncover slowly as time goes on. The game has a delightful amount of sublety as well. Many character relations and connections are not spelled out to the player, but can be discovered instead. 

The game sports a "True Ending", which is not mutually exclusive from any other ending choice though! You can still get any job or any love interest (barring one) if you get the True Ending. It reveals a lot of plot points that were only hinted at across the game and can be quite challenging to achieve. I doubt many players will get it on their first playthrough. Right now a few things about the plot are still rather vague or confusing to me, but I have also not done everything the game has to offer yet!

[b][u]Other points[/u][/b]
The English translation can be a bit lacking in certain parts of the game. The overall translation effort is good and most of it is understandable. The quality differences between certain events or descriptions are very noticable however. The devs are updating the game a lot and have already improved a lot of things, including the translation, so my hope is that eventually the quality will be on the same level everywhere.

You can pick between Chinese or Japanese voice options, but the only character who is really voiced is the daughter. I personally prefered the Japanese performance, but this is very subjective. Either way the voice work is very good. And it's not like all her lines are voiced, it is only specific scenes. Otherwise every character has distinctive noises they make.

The game's save system is a bit limited. You can only save at the start of a month/the turn, meaning that if you reload the game you start from the beginning of the day. This means if you wish to quickly redo a choice or activity you will have to go through the entire day again. This probably is meant to disincentivize save scumming and make you stick with decisions, but it is not very fun for me personally.

The game has exploits, but if you are looking for them then that's probably your prefered playstyle. They may be patched out later or maybe they won't.

The music is really good actually. From calm background music to themes that stick in your head, the game's composition feels almost classical and very inspired. The sound effects are on a similar caliber. Just hovering over icons gives completely different sound responses and level up noises and the like are all soooo satisfying.

[b][u]Replay value[/u][/b]
Incredible. Collossal.

138177617.review:
( full review with screenshots: https://www.gaming-parrot.com/2023/05/volcano-princess-review-volcano-maker.html )

Volcano Princess is a Princess Maker-style game from a Chinese indie studio. Both of these facts will be obvious from within a few seconds of starting the game. It's proudly inspired by PM and borrows mechanics and ideas liberally, but generally does so with updates and reimaginings that make it much more than a shallow copy. Alas, being obviously from a Chinese studio is down to the English text being absolutely riddled with errors typical of translation from Chinese. It's by no means the worst example I've ever seen, and you're not going to get anything as bad as older translation gems like Zero Wing, but you do need to be prepared for a lot of strange turns of phrase and a smaller amount of unclear or incorrect descriptions. If you played Chinese Parents around when it first launched in English, the translation quality is similar.

Still, assuming you can get past that, nearly everything else about the game is very well done. Like the good Princess Maker titles, it reduces raising a kid to scheduling a whole bunch of classes and jobs over their childhood, then gives you some scenes at the end about how you've either raised an absolute monster or the hero of the world. Also like some PM games, there are multiple combat systems for the daughter to go and kill monsters with, as well as a couple of other minigames like horse racing or playing dice. None of it is very deep or necessarily balanced, but there's so much of it that you can easily go through a few playthroughs without repeating very much of the side content. 

Speaking of multiple playthroughs, VP very much expects you to play it more than once. You're not practically guaranteed to be a failure on your first run like in Chinese Parents, but the best endings seem clearly out of reach until you've upgraded your starting character a few times. Each finished run gives you some points depending on what you did, and those points provide you with better starting stats or items so you can get to those better endings. As a bonus, this also lets you quickly blow past the early game content that you've already seen. 

I've also seen this compared to Long Live the Queen a few times, but I think you'll be disappointed if that game is primarily what you're after. LLtQ is mostly about trying to navigate a world full of absurd deathtraps trying to stop your game early. I don't think it's possible to die at all in VP, and the focus is much more on the daughter's relationships with the player character and NPCs than on running any kingdoms. Similarly, if you want something like Cute Knight, know that the combat and dungeons here are much more basic. 

I generally prefer these games when they're like Cute Knight or Growing Up and cast you as the main character instead of a parent since it's a bit less creepy, but I will say that Volcano Princess is much better in that regard than Princess Maker. VP goes out of its way to show that the daughter has agency and her own concerns, and what she thinks of you is it's own objective and part of the ending. It hasn't changed my opinion that I'd rather play as the kid directly, but VP is probably the best alternative I've seen so far.

--------
For more reviews, see [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/43219041]my curator page[/url]

138162897.review:
I only tend to write reviews when a game really disappoints me, or really astounds me with how good it ends up being.  Volcano Princess was the second.  I bought this game with absolutely no expectations, simply off the 'game style' which seemed rather generic on the surface, and the overwhelmingly positive reviews.  The reason it is so highly rated was quickly apparently.  The depths of the game has had me playing it religiously for the past three days.  I beat it once, then immediately started a second play-through and beat it again within those three days.

If I could complain about anything (and lets face it, I always can), it's either the translation or lack of certain things being finished.  I don't want to give spoilers but some things are so vague it's apparent that there is some sort of language mishap going on, or it's a feature not fully implemented.  29 hours played, been through it twice, nowhere near done everything in the game (though I can see how after a couple times through certain aspects could become repetitive).

Unlike most of these style games, the choices really do matter.  A lot.  But they matter so much that they don't matter for completing the game.  There's so many endings and choices, and you don't have to be a big hero.  First time I just ended up as a great music composer.    I haven't even touched alchemy, horse riding, stealing, or several other aspects of the game because there's so much to do that I don't think you can manage to do everything to any degree of proficiency in just one go.

This is a game that I really hope gets even more added to it, because it's already robust enough to warrant multiple plays.

138150560.review:
TLDR: The latest Princess Maker, in all but name. 

This is a fantastic entry as far as a Raising Sim is concerned. 

It does pretty much everything right. Gorgeous Art, varied dialogue and options, interesting characters with backgrounds to discover and many, many endings to shoot for. 

It also serves as a great introduction to the genre by slowly enabling options through the first playthrough, and through subsequent playthroughs these mechanics can be skipped past extremely quickly. 

The game incentivizes repeat playthroughs through it's copious amounts of achievements serving an actual purpose. Achieve something, and you get points to spend towards your next attempt. Giving you that incentive to try something new and experiment with the options available to you. 

Unlike other games in this genre, the Father figure is not a completely devoid character detached from the experience. You have goals made for yourself as well. Which takes some effort to figure out how your choices relate to the overall goal. 

There is a story to this with some wonderful foreshadowing in various ways for those willing to pay attention. 

Edit: The game does have an appropriate ending, it just took a fourth play-through to get to. That addresses the questions I had as far as the plot was concerned. So I figured I'd edit my review to account for that. 

If I would want to nitpick things:

There are some grammatical and spelling mistakes in the English version, which are being worked on. Some characters are called by the wrong name, feature name changes depending on menu, and other shenanigans happening, leading to some confusion on who they are. Some character names in particular make little sense in English. Rebsa/Lebsa, one of the Knight Lords being one such example. 

I would like to see what choices related to choosing Blood Type and what it actually impacts, since that's not something native to my Country. So I have no idea what my choices mean, if anything at all. With how useless Google Search has become: finding useful and relevant information is such a huge pain, it's almost not worth it. Even for recreational stuff. I just want to be able to make a more informed choice here. 

So whether you are a fan of this genre of game, or someone whose interested in giving this type of game a shot. I can highly recommend Volcano Princess for being a great way to get introduced to this style of game and a fantastic take for those familiar with the style. 

With how Achievements feature as a means to improve your starting stats and abilities: it's a fantastic way to get some replay value. As each subsequent playthrough can unlock more potential endings and making the initial setup shorter and shorter each time. Opening up additional personal challenges and goals.

138121801.review: I've seen a lot of comparisons to Long Live the Queen and I can say, with complete certainty, that this game surpasses Long Live the Queen. The characters are more enjoyable, the world feels really lived in, and overall it's just a more enjoyable experience in terms of story. There were some complaints about translation that I saw but, as of version 1.014, the translation is pretty good. There are a few parts where it's rough but not bad at all and completely understandable. If you have any interest at all in games like this don't pass this up! This was clearly a product of love and it shows.

138094080.review:
First of all, stop. This is a multiple playthrough game with carryover benefits between runs and that is important to know. My first run through I was surprised how easily and massively I failed at everything, by late game I was starting to develop stats/skills and enjoyed it more but the second playthrough was definitely the more fun one. I'm on my third playthrough now and there are a load of endings you can shoot for but you can definitely max out the second playthrough if you want. 

The game had a lot of broken text early-on and I can't tell if it has been mostly patched out or if I just don't notice it as much but it isn't a big deal. 

While there's not any really satisfying romance options, if you like visual novels I imagine that this will be up your alley. I personally just love stat maxing and roguelites so I found a lot of enjoyment. It feels a bit like Persona 5 with far less combat and less relatable characters. 

A fairly large flaw in the game is that it clearly wasn't finished, several items have no purpose other than sale and according to the community page there was a more in-depth magic/alchemy system in the works. So unfortunately all those cool artifacts and magic ingredients you get are just pointless entirely. I am hopeful they will patch this in future. 

Overall I recommend this game and continue to get my money's worth out of it. It's really satisfying to smash through all the early challenges that were previously insurmountable and I'm getting enough enjoyment out of focusing on different goals. 

Value for money this is a hands down 10/10, I would pay $40 for it at most I think as it stands now and with some writing refinements, more content, and more variation for the 5th+ run where you will certainly have everything unlocked even if you didn't min/max, I would see paying $60 for a version of this game.

138063261.review:
Having played and loved other raising games like Princess Maker 2 and Long Live the Queen, I adore Volcano Princess. Its a streamlined and lovely successor to the Princess Maker style child raising game legacy. The art is beautiful, I LOVE that there are both male and female love interests for the daughter that are equally and explicitly romantic. Raising stats and getting endings is straightforward with only some finesse needed to get the highest stat endings (the requirements are in the collection gallery for all endings). I like the story and think that it is a very fresh and unique take on the [spoiler] child of/from god in the [/spoiler] Princess Maker series. Yes, there are some translation issues but the games for the majority reads and can easily be understood in English so I would say translation issues are minor in the story imo -- and the devs are very actively working on fixing and improving these issues-- I would say the biggest issue translation wise is in the achievement names/ some of the achievements names are mistakenly switched. I really love this game and recommend it if you have enjoyed Princess Maker/ Raising Sim games in the past!

Pros: 
- beautiful art
- fresh paint on a beloved classic
- male and female romance options [spoiler] and group [/spoiler]
- easy text skipping
- achieving endings is straightforward and the stats and requirements are easily found
- enjoyable music
- active game devs working on improving the game and fixing bugs every week (as of writing this review)

Cons
- some (overall minor) translation issues in the main story/text of the game
- some annoying bugs cropping up here and there (devs have been good about fixing these quickly)
- achievements names are often swapped and mis named so it can be confusing to achieve them

137909304.review:
In this review I am going to talk about:
-The story
-The visuals
-The adorable
-The price
and many more.
First of all this review is written with only one ending finished out of like sixty.

-THE STORY:
+It is engaging.
+It is absolutely adorable, especially early on.
+Has an amazing twist (IMHO)
+It is extremely customizable with the exception of a few scripted events.
+Every character has a personality that actually adds to a character.
-/+ It is quite long. (I took my time on my first play and it took 12 hours)
-Some dialogue will get boring after a few runs, especially if you want to 100% achievement grind it.

-THE ADORABLE:
+Every ending has a different end card.
+Your daughter is absolutely adorable.
+Sometimes it will go to an old tale kind of art stile for memories.

-THE PRICE:
+It is a robbery, as in you rob the developer. There is so much content in this game and so much love that I recommend it to anyone who is into slice of life or visual novels.

-ESTIMATED PLAY TIME
+There are 58 different endings, I'd say it takes about 8 hours/ending after you the first run, bringing the 100% play time if everything is done perfectly to 9 days and 12 hours of constant playing without break or sleep.
+Certain endings or collectibles are harder to obtain, so it might take you more to 100% than 9 and a half days.

-This game is an achievement collectors wet dream or lucid nightmare.

-The music:
-It is nothing special, some of it I think, is free use music but it does not hurt the game that much.

-If you start Playing this game you might just play for a 12 hours straight just to see the ending.

137909031.review:
De lo mejorcito dentro del genero. De verdad, un muy buen juego de "crianza". 

Por un lado simplifican de buena manera la cantidad de habilidades y status desbordante de otros títulos. Pero manteniendo una clara personificación de como va creciendo.  Algo que se cumple muy bien gracias a que tienes muchas cosas que hacer en el mapa de la ciudad, cosas que; estudiar, trabajar, un dungeon, duelos, carreras de caballo, actuacion, etc... y por ende varios mini juegos.

Siendo este el punto mas interesante, ademas el juego tiene una enorme cantidad de personajes secundarios y por ende una gran cantidad de eventos. Cumpliendo en variedad y desarrollo. 
Especialmente por la enorme cantidad de finales según el desempeño y la formación de tu hija.  Destacándose, y se agradece, que se puede escoger entre distintas opciones de finales. Lo cual facilita el farmeo de finales/cgi y amplia la experiencia de juego.

Si tuviera algo que quejarme seria la falta de decisiones importantes para desarrollar la historia principal y por ende variantes importantes en está. lo otro seria que varios mini juegos son demasiado simplones y/o que terminan siendo algo redundantes/repetitivos. Lo cual podría mejorar. Pero como tal, el juego cumple bien.

Adicionalmente el juego contiene la opción de un New+Game, lo cual es siempre bueno.
En resumen, recomendado especialmente si gustas de los juegos estilo Princess Maker.

137853486.review:
Volcano Princess is a stat-raising game where you raise your daughter until she turns 18 (or when her schooling ends) and what you choose for your daughter will decide what she will do in her adulthood.

This game is very much like Princess Maker so it was a no-brainer that I would get it. I can say confidently that I enjoyed this game thoroughly. It was addicting and highly replayable and had bonuses in case you finished a playthrough that can make your next new game easier which was a nice touch for those who want to complete the game 'easier'.

The story/plot was also very interesting, I won't spoil it here though, also the setting was also nice. It had a nice amount of gameplay aside from lessons, in fact, I'd say the rest day is where you'll be spending a good amount of time aside from the lessons to increase your daughter's stats.

It also has a lot of characters that you can befriend, duel, date and of course, marry. All of them I found to be very interesting and likable (yes all), and I enjoyed being able to marry them and still have a career at the same time. Also, this game is great for having poly marriage ends for some candidates. Never saw that in a SIM game and I applaud them for doing so.

Now for the Cons of this game. The translations are not that great. They are readable but you can tell it's not polished but it shouldn't ruin the game for you.

Also, it has too few save files, for a stat-raising game it should have more than 8-10 save files in case we need to backtrack...

Overall, if you loved princess maker, you will also love this game, it's fun, engaging, and has a lot of replayability.

Very cutesy! If you're looking for a modern-day Princess Maker, this would be exactly what you want. The art style is gorgeous, and each character is unique and cute/handsome.

On top of that, there's no weirdly romantic father-daughter relationship happening. It's simply a wholesome relationship between you (the father) and your daughter. 
Unfortunately, the English translation isn't exactly the best. Sometimes it's hard to figure out what is happening due to poor translation, but it's not impossible.
I recommend the game if you enjoyed princess maker or are interested in trying out this game.

137814974.review:
First, a trigger warning. I do discuss this in the review, and while I still personally like the game- it has a MASSIVE * on it for this. This game is incredibly disrespectful to the daughter. There is a lot of borderline harassment in the form of "love letters". If you were abused growing up; as much as this game is actually fairly fun either avoid reading said letters or avoid the game all together. Fair warning.

There is a very niche collection of game titles starting with the Princess Maker series. They are like a combination of an incremental game and a roguelike, though they predate both concepts. The genre is a subset of a life sim I call a "raising simulator". Volcano Princess does its best to recreate this niche but well defined genre in a way which has both positives and negatives. 

During this review, I will be comparing this game to others in the genre; for comparison's sake I have played the following games in this genre. Princess Maker 2, Ciel Fledge and Growing Up. I will be referring to each of these titles throughout the review; but I assume that this applies to other games in the genre too. 

First the good; Volcano Princess does a fantastic job at creating an accessible life sim; capturing the appeal of the original Princess Maker rather well. It contains all the same hallmarks and more; you schedule your child's day, explore the town, dungeon dive and more! Unlike Ciel Fledge, the game doesn't punish you for wanting to explore, and instead does a good job at encouraging it. Every day you are wasting time and resources if you don't first explore the town, talk to people and do your best to participate in one of the many side activities you slowly unlock as your daughter ages. It has a solid and refined Visual Novel element, with many ways you can interact with each person, even if it does seem a little too checklisty at times. Of particular note is both the dungeon crawling and cooking systems; which play off eachother well to provide an alternative method of levelling your stats. 

Most of your primary stat gains occur not during your scheduled timeslots, but during the exploration element. You must make choices using your stamina on if you refine skills or participate in activities; though the game is not very restrictive in this due to the aforementioned cooking system. Over time you gain ingredients which either buff your skills directly, or increase your action points allowing you to participate in more stat or money making activities. The schedule side focuses more on completing a series of "classes"- similar to the skills system in "Growing Up", but with the addition of various "Extra Curriculars" that provide additional abilities and even buffs to your character. Speaking of buffs, beyond those unlocked through normal play, Volcano Princess includes multiple other forms of progression. Combat Levelling for you (and any companions you befriend high enough to battle with you in one of four selected dungeons),  Skills, which unlock with skill points over time and unlock other additional gamechanging modifiers to double or improve rewards in places you would like, mind body and charisma tokens (gained when completing courses, make activities better and unlock new content), guild achievements, regular achievements and more. Honestly I am absolutely impressed by the wide range of progression options throughout this game. I haven't even mentioned all of them, as every single activity levels up, new places unlock- there is a whole horse breeding minigame which is both easy and rewarding... Gawd. The game is both too long and too short at the same time to be honest. 

Unlike something like Ciel Fledge which lasts for an entire ten year spread; Volcano Princess has several time skips which lead to you feeling rather cheated as you seem to feel like part of your daughter's childhood was stolen away from them. What's worse is that while the art for your daughter does mildly change over time, the spritework keeps her looking like a tiny baby throughout the entire game. What's worse is, all of her various love interests can be met when she is very young, and unlike the aforementioned Ciel Fledge, they do NOT age over time with you, instead already seem like young adults right from when your daughter is 10. Not only does it seem really strange that your daughter can randomly date a bunch of people who are much MUCH older than her; the number of creepy and disturbing letters she gets throughout is... disgusting. 

These letters are to the point where, despite liking the gameplay very much, I stopped paying any attention to the dialogue outside of important events. Everyone will hit on your daughter even from age 10, she gets loads of creepy letters from guys saying how they would die for her- and there isn't even any way to say to eff off. No, you get to say thank you, and get a mood boost from reading a wall of disgusting messages. This would honestly be a massive red flag and even a total dealbreaker if I was unlucky enough to had been involved in this sort of stuff while growing up. Instead I just chalked it up to a cultural difference I don't understand. While this game isn't as abusive in its narrative as Ciel Fledge can be, it is still a big downer that I hope can be improved with further localisation. You are allowed to be a good dad, but due to the way the game arbitrarily decides the meaning of "gentle" and "kind"- it can be VERY hard to get a top dad score your first playthrough... and anything to do with bravery and such is much easier to nail down than gentle and kind, at least in my experience. 

In more "stuff that bothers me likely caused by a cultural difference more than anything"- the religious overtones in this game are far far too much. Everything in this place is belief, religion and nothing aside. Even the so called "science" pathway is just a "faith" pathway. While this isn't a problem in of itself, it does end up being very much on the nose. You have no choice but to either follow the religion entirely- or get too much "darkness". What does "darkness" do you may ask? Literally nothing but lock you out from some of the best endings unless you repent or entirely avoid anything the game deems as dark. I can understand some jobs in a bathhouse may involve too much skin for a small child sure, but you also get darkness from acting, fighting crimes, stating any kind of opposition to authority. Thankfully, most of the worst options the dad can say also bequeaths the penalty too, which is positive. But I didn't like how central the religious themes were. It really gave me the sense that this society really wasn't going to progress at all, and the world that my child was in would continue to be horrible regardless of her options. The temple is one of the most important places in the game, due in part to the darkness mechanic, but also due to it being the home to the only way to trade fame into free course completion. Given the limited time of the game, this is annoyingly unavoidable. 

Anyway, back to the good to finish off. The game is fun, open, and not overly difficult. While I still prefer Growing Up (due to the length, freedom, music and more contemporary setting), I do think Volcano Princess is worth a look if you like these sort of games and don't feel as bothered by the- troubling elements. I hope that given its positive reception, we start to see some patches for the game to improve the localisation to remove these issues; and flesh out the game more (even through DLC, I'd pay for more if it offered enough incentive).

Just from looking at the pictures, you may conclude that this game is some sort of a visual novel or a JRPG, but you would be wrong about that. This is instead a resource management game with a lot of story parts, which is a pretty neat combination. The story goes as follows: you're a single father and your goal is to raise your daughter as competently as you can. That's how the game starts at least, but as your daughter hits a certain age you start playing as her instead for the most part. But the goal remains the same, with your actions, choices of studies, and friendships you try to sculpt an independent grown-up with a set of goals, morals, and a profession. 

I really like the idea of this game and while the execution might not be perfect – it's clear how much love was put into making this game.

137695280.review:
This is the indie Princess Maker you've been waiting for.

A passion project with an extremely small team, Volcano Princess was released with some substantial bugs. But even so, this is a solid and beautifully presented dating sim. There's a huge quantity of art; there's substantial breadth of options for activities, love interests, and endings; it is not punishing, so it's easy to jump in and you won't totally screw up your first run if you don't come in armed with a spreadsheet; each playthrough takes a while but is not a laboriously long slog; I especially appreciate that it has a New Game+ feature, so every playthrough can assist you with your next one, if you choose to take advantage of that feature.

You should know that gameplay is very, VERY heavily RNG-based, and you can only save at the end of a turn (one month). This makes it very difficult to pre-plan your runs in detail; instead, it encourages you instead to have a flexible, broader-picture strategy and roll with the punches. There's pros and cons to this. I find it a bit aggravating, but typically, if RNG throws off your plan you'll have time to recover.

Because this is a small indie game, the breadth of options available does mean that they tend to be a bit shallow. I wish love interests and career paths had a bit more depth and distinction from one another, but this is only a small complaint.

The English translation is variable; it appears they have a fluent translator for some sections while others are not fluently translated. Unfortunately, the introduction to the game is one of the poorly translated sections, giving a first impression of a slapdash job. But, over the 1.5 weeks it's been out, the devs have been really involved not just fixing bugs but improving the translation. Such a level of love and care on the part of the devs is unlike pretty much every raising sim I've looked at.

If this genre is your thing, I think you should buy it. For me, no other game has scratched the Princess Maker 2 itch as well.

137626086.review:
A cute take on princess maker game with a biological father who can either take part or be somewhat neglectful in shaping up the little princess. The game is a bit off beat in that it's translations can be rough sometimes, but it shouldn't bother anyone who isn't a stickler or struggles to read English. Sometimes I'd pause and get mentally stuck cause I'm a bit of a literalist, but then I'd laugh at myself about it. The mechanics are great and fun, and I feel there is a lot of replayability due to the impact of RNG on the game. It's not too hard, and there is a 1-3 run learning curve if you're an optimizer like myself, but there is room for creative approaches. After you beat the game once you can add legacy traits/boosts which significantly help the freedom of choice for how to direct your princess' lifestyle and choices/interests. The storyline is really cute and enjoyable and I think there are some secrets to be found there depending on what ending you get or what you focus on and there is definitely enough content to explore. 

The only negatives I have is that some parts of the mini games are not skippable, but honestly it's not that big of a deal. 

The voice acting isn't in english but it seems pretty good for someone who doesn't speak those languages. 

The support team has continued to work on and fix bugs they find which is a good sign. Personally I've had no bugs or issues playing the game, and look forward to any updates they may add. :)

I recommend this game if you like stardew valley, Princess maker type games, visual novels and turn based combat games. But you don't have to engage in the farming, novel, or combat aspects if you don't want to, the game is versatile.

137614942.review:
音乐、美术都是优良+。很让我欣赏的一点是每一个角色都很立体，有细节。印象很深的，是有一次找大主教辩论，华丽地将智商天花板干翻，然后他说：“希望我们都能从这次辩论中有所收获。”顿时觉得自己幼稚不堪，始终是翻不出主教的手掌心。（还是格局小了，主教教导我们应该为他人身上的物品，而非嘴炮他人的快感去辩论）

其实在开始游戏之前让我嫁女儿我内心是拒绝的，（但谁知道竟然可以百合！！！）但谁知道成功的角色塑造地让人难以拒绝它。游戏里地恋爱，不突兀，不娇柔做作，不时间管理（时间管理可能还是有那么一点点额），美丽阳光勤奋（勤奋是我逼的）又善于聆听的小公主用真诚、时间、与善良一步步加深与生活中值得珍惜的人们的羁绊，这些关系和与朋友的记忆“像金子一样在记忆里闪闪发光”。擅长照顾人，但时常显得神秘寂寞的莫娜姐姐；聪慧美丽、优秀能干杰出、严于律己，但内心十分渴求信任、友情、与爱的公主；冷峻沉默、悲伤勇敢，在情感上果断忠诚的泽；除了这些讨喜的标签外，他们都懂得珍重身边的人，珍惜友谊与爱情，以不同的表现形式散发着人性美好的光。以上所有，让这个游戏的感情结局水到渠成，修成正果的主角，留给人以有情人终成眷属的感慨
。
一周目一开始处处碰壁确实很气馁，但坚持拿着剧院一半的收入，一步一步的攒钱攒经验，最终S级演出信手拈来是真的很有成就感。二周目之后就开启了凤傲天模式，所有活动（指探险，赛马，舞台之类的）都轻松杀穿，开始有计划地学习、消费，始终向着一个美好而不平凡的未来迈进，为之努力奋斗。老婆（请务必让我这么称呼doge）一遍又一遍的尝试，见证了24次双女的死亡，她说：“我感觉自己太笨了。”但爱的慰藉与支撑让她始终不放弃对幸福的追求，这份追求，可能就是火山女神与她女儿口中的“偏执”，也是所有坐在屏幕前玩家全心投入、不断尝试的原因： 一个平凡或不平凡 的 幸福的 美好的 为之奋斗的 生活。
所以说我家小公主和小天使天下无敌第一（并列）可爱！！！！！


最后凭着残缺的记忆聊一聊勇者和剧情。首先，我是没有打学园长线和恶堕线的，所以关于应该是缺少了部分剧情关键信息的（尤其是那个大退化和那个石碑），但就姑且这么谈把。我个人对勇者的定性是：可悲之人。至于可不可怜，就确实有待讨论了。其实小公主最后信中表达的对勇者（当然在啥都不知道的憨憨老爹前叫的是雷贝莎）的情感是倾向可怜的。小公主将勇者称呼为自己的朋友，虽然总抱怨她阴晴不定。小公主说她对勇者的感情比较复杂，小公主窥见、也或多或少理解了勇者“疯“之下的痛苦与挣扎；他/她千真万确的伤害了小公主的家庭，但他/她的痛苦也是真实的，他/她对小公主也真的动了情，也曾真的想过说和小公主一起做一个平凡的骑士（勇者战之前这里说的应该是勇者的压力，但勇者战之后回头来看其实应该是指的是对永生与力量漫长的痛苦追寻（毕竟勇者说自己打架其实挺爽的，所以大概不会讨厌打架）），但无论如何，他/她最终还是在这一条痛苦的罪孽之路走了下去，他/她杀死我老婆（doge）（其实也没杀死）（打个岔，红石头不是加幸运吗？要红的干嘛？？？），对小天使下手，注定了他/她的罪恶，也注定了他/她的结局。我认为勇者是可悲而可怜的，可怜在他/她疯狂之下的软弱与痛苦。

剧情方面先列举一些事实和推测把（可能措辞不是很准确）欢迎指正：
关于夺舍事件：
1.	发生在小鸟节，勇者说的，与之对应的是游戏一章结尾的落崖事件
2.	女儿（不知道是哪一个）在该事件落崖，父亲也落崖，父亲没死，留下了腿伤
3.	父亲在夺舍事件前后始终都只有一个女儿的记忆
4.	夺舍之后姐姐的灵魂仍残存在身体里（勇者的说法）

关于神力
1.	打倒魔兽会掉落红石头和紫石头。游戏中的红石头可以带来幸运，紫石头可以强化等级。勇者最后吸收/使用了母亲掉的红石头，称之为“鲜活的力量”，并说他生前最后只能靠这个才能存活，而姐姐的“身体”“充满“了这种力量，而妹妹的“身体”则毫无这种力量。
2.	姐姐提到，妹妹继承了凡人的躯体，无法承载神力，并且导致了妹妹其他世界线的死亡，虽然没说24次分别是啥原因死的，但这至少是最根本最初始的原因。讲堂里《不祥的邪术》提到的“对宿主十分要求苛刻“指的应该是不是神力，不然几乎不可能有成功的先例，更不用提文字记载。合理的推测是，红紫石头中存在的力量应该属于类似于某种生命力的力量，这种力量是魔兽表现出来，而正常人表现不明显的，而神力表现出很强的这种力量
3.	姐姐被夺舍后“灵魂”仍然存在（虽然勇者的灵魂在肉体灭了之后就散了）（一开始在勇者身体里），“灵魂“仍然拥有”力量“，尽管“力量”被削弱了，但力量可以恢复，恢复之后有能力再创造身体（关于这一点，姐姐的说法是很简单，不排除安慰妹妹的可能性高，但看无勇者战结局，确实是又造了一个身体，至少不会很难）。推测，“灵魂“是不依附于”肉体“存在的，勇者的最终死亡可以用失去了肉体，而灵魂没有能力创造肉体（不像姐姐）所以”消散在森林中“来解释。妹妹和勇者一样时常也梦到姐姐最后姐姐跑出来救场，总结也支持这个说法，而勇者说的姐姐”灵魂“残存在他/她身体里，不过是他/她片面的一家之言
4.	尽管“身体”毫无神力，但妹妹依然成神了。那么问题来了，妹妹到底有没有神力？个人认为比较合理的解释是出生是没有的，但在后天成长的过程中，不管说是四值三值的成长，还是说吸收了红紫石头升级了，还是妈妈又想出了什么法子，或者三者兼有之，使身体可以承受神力。综合姐姐，应该和三值四值没什么关系（毕竟像爸爸所以笨应该是玩笑话）。

关于母亲之“死“
1.	母亲是在结婚10周年纪念日之后“死“的
2.	母亲“死”前和父亲一起起了“名字“，推测是双胞胎，所以怀孕期间只取了一个“名字”
，长得很一模一样可以佐证，小天使说“我们的名字“也可以佐证，所以婚后十年再生孩子就当一开始没心情吧。
3.	母亲“死“前（推测在怀孕期间）进行了分草药事件，推测（这个基本上等于是事实）这里是在推演拯救两个女儿的方法（也就是说如果确实是双胞胎那这里已经知道了），母亲说草药混在一起，父亲用滤纸将两种草药分开了。大谜语人。这里可能暗指将两个女儿的命运分开，这解释了为什么玩家一直只看到了妹妹，但这目前并不能解释为什么让她们走向被分开的路线（姐姐被夺舍）对妹妹会有一丁点好处。还可能暗指将所有的神力都分给姐姐，这能很好解释怎么救下女儿，但这个暗指本身有点牵强。更重要的是，这两点都目前不能很好的解释为什么妈妈要离开。
4.	游戏中没有提及母亲死亡的时间及原因，只是在草药回忆后说“如果当时多注意你的身体“暗示了是难产（虽然根本不对）。这种模糊化处理可以理解为父亲对于母亲的死亡本身就是模糊的，只是潜意识地将其合理化了。这里可以推测是母亲的神力干预的结果，也同时可以作为父亲记忆中只有一个女儿的解释，那么问题就来了，分别是为什么？一个合理的推测要回到上一条，即母亲发现拯救两个女儿的方法是将她们的命运分开，让父亲养妹妹，母亲养姐姐，（而且事实证明这是成功的，不论有没有经历勇者战事件，姐妹和父亲都活了下去）而为了这样一个设计，需要给身为凡人的父亲和妹妹一点合理的背景，而母亲和姐姐，身为神，是知晓这一切的。
5.	当然上一个问题想讲清楚要涉及另一个问题，即究竟是什么威胁了姐妹的生命。我们知道只要完成了勇者战事件，母亲就“活“了（不过我不知道该事件中途放弃会发生什么，欢迎补充），而没触发，就一直”死“着。结合其他内容考虑，可以推测勇者是主要威胁。勇者夺舍了姐姐活了下去，或许姐姐确实没有死，但放任勇者这样下去终究是个威胁。然而作为一个平民家庭，理应无论是说实力还是权势都无法与勇者抗衡的，所以就只能作为魔兽之主物理外耗，然后姐姐精神内耗。在结局中，要么把勇者耗死了；要么就一直这样僵持了下去，没让勇者对家庭造成更多伤害了。所以从结果论来看，这是很合理的。另外，从父亲的性格，从始至终的生活（包括各种结局），以及妹妹生而为人的事实，都表明了南港的小房子才是夫妻享受与追求的安稳的不用不平凡的幸福，因此从始至终母亲都没有公开自己身份的打算（导致最后只有憨憨父亲蒙在鼓里），这是母亲选择离开的考量之一。题外话，母亲对父亲的爱与信任让她能将妹妹托付给他，相信他能凭坚强与爱培育浇灌他们最可爱的小公主，让她健康、开心的长大。

关于大退化
1.	人与动物都会发生大退化，动物会变成魔物，掉落红紫石头，人会长出羽毛、改变骨骼结构（目前只有这一种现象）。
2.	首先是动物发生了大退化、再是父亲、再是其他人类。推测是跟地理位置有关。
3.	父亲说，大退化是“出于‘某人的意志‘”；母亲（罪魁祸首）说，大退化是因为“太想团圆了”。
4.	综合以上，推测大退化和神力有关，可能和母亲无意识的神力释放有关（因为思念或伤痛）。这也再一次印证了神力中关于红紫石头中力量和神力有关的观点。

玩了这么多结局果然还是喜欢格温妮斯，公主x公主天下第一！！！！！！

137550629.review:
[b]  Volcano Princess was featured on my YouTube channel [/b]


 https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2969326421




and now onto the short review

[h1]TL;DR Review[/h1]




//intro//

Welcome back comrades, this is MF Kraven & you are watching less than 10 mins reviews. The Youtube series where I take a look at games i think seem cool & give my thoughts on them in less than 10 mins.

Today I will be taking a look at Volcano Princess. Volcano Princess is a life sim RPG adventure game about raising the next monarch, your daughter. Help shape her youth for her to grow into an outstanding adult to rule over the Volcano Kingdom as a single father, will you be enough to help make your little girl great? Let's find out! 

//Graphics, Sound & Artstyle//

I just have to say straight up, I'm not a fan of anime. I've watched Death Note & that's about it- however this artstyle has me in awe. Have I been depraving myself of content? The menu music accompanies it nicely & it feels all very regal. I have the voice set to Chinese, and sometimes the Princess voice can be annoying but it's such a minor detail, I don't mind it.


//Gameplay//

Being a choose your own adventure simulator RPG it sort of feels like it's a visual novel of sorts but with a deep stats based mechanic. You will have to guide your daughter from a young age to help navigate the world, as she gets older more spots are available to visit. Here she can do tasks according to however many action points she has. Things like reading from her bookcase can help her raise her intelligence, listening to stories can help her develop her emotion, trips down a river can help build her strength etc etc. All of those stats help her with the courses she will be taking when trying to become a knight, at the end of each day you will help her plan courses so that she can finish courses- leveling up her Strength, Intelligence, Emotion, & Image will make the courses finish much faster and unlock more. 

There are other factors such as darkness, patience, fame & admirers that will influence the life of your daughter and three main attributes that will affect everything like Strength (that will determine your ability in battle), Mind (affecting ability in debates), Charisma (affecting ability in dances & part time jobs). It sounds incredibly complicated but honestly once you start getting the hang of things, its like a satisfying game full of strategy. 

I don't want to spoil much as advertised a play-through should be approximately around 8 hours. Part of the charm of this game is learning new mechanics and how everything effects everything. As deep as who you make friendships with to what jobs you choose to complete as the father- everything and with 18 love interests (7 female, 11 male) there is a lite dating game also to unravel within this, as well as a lite JRPG dungeon.


//Price//

10.99 USD


//How many hours estimated//

As previously aforementioned each play-through is approximately 8 hours. But with 50+ endings as well. I can't really estimate, however I can say that I will be playing through the game a few times (granted I feel like I'm doing really awesome and might get a great ending),

//Is it playable on SteamDeck?//

Yes it is absolutely playable on SteamDeck and I almost prefer to play it handheld because I can just lay in bed and be the best dad I can be.


//Final Thoughts//

Volcano Princess is a DEEP game. There's so much to do that it's almost intimidating. You can be an actress in plays, you can catch horses, plant, romance 18 different people, shoot dice with the villagers, engage in illegal horse races, explore a dark alley, fight in dungeons, have a stable- I mean with so much to do, with so many different ways to playing the game, you can lead your daughter to be a saint, someone to be revered or a complete an utter fascist.... but I find myself caring more and more for this little girl & wanting to make the protagonists late wife proud of the little girl I'm raising. 

It's certainly an experience that many people should get to, well- experience. It's cute, witty & more importantly tons of fun. As soon as I saw this game, I knew I had to play it. It reminded me of one of my all time favorite games, Chinese Parents. And it plays a lot like it too but set in a magical world. I find myself wanting more content like Volcano Princess, so I'm gonna be looking into visual novels, and games of this genre. It's certainly left an impression on me, however there are some bad remarks.

Translations aren't the best, sometimes there are obvious misspellings and it isn't the end of the world but seeing the words like that irks me just a bit. Only some of the dialogue is voice acted, and other text you can hear either grunts or sighs- and at first I thought I didn't mind it, but i found myself muting the voice and just letting the music play. A guide or "study book" should be a thing, because i still don't know what impressions are for and it was only after a few months that i found using up my allotted patience would help me build more skills faster. Some words are lost in translation and while the devs are updating the game regularly, I tend to be cautious as when I started playing I had a game breaking bug that prevented me from advancing, when that was fixed another bug appeared that could potentially delete all my save data. It's the main reason I took so long with this review. 

Despite all that fuss though, I really enjoy the game. Volcano Princess really amazed me, and whether naming the princess after my IRL daughter made me care for her even more- I just find myself wanting to be the best that I can be for that little girl. I don't know what I was expecting with Volcano Princess other than similar mechanics as Chinese Parents but it is rapidly becoming one of my all time favorite games. Would I recommend it? Hell yes.


[h1]Buy it Now![/h1]

Pretty fun to build your daughter up to fit whatever career you want her to have - you can choose from something charisma, mind or stamina (strength) based. First time around, you're going to have to choose to focus on only one or two of them, but 2nd time, with all the stat boosts you can get, your daughter can be an all-rounder.

Translation is pretty good considering the 2-person studio, but some bits either aren't well explained, badly translated, or both, so you might have to figure things out for yourself.

Love interests for your daughter (which include basically everyone she can talk to) are almost all 5+ years older than her, so might be a bit weird if you think about it, but they all have their charms.

Plot's not the greatest - there essentially isn't one until near the end, and only if you send your daughter down the martial path - but plot isn't really the focus of this game. 

If they decide to make a sequel, would be nice to be able to influence things like your daughter's personality - feels like the protagonists of games like these have near-identical personalities.

137431328.review:
The Good:
-It's the closest you'll get to modern day Princess Maker
-It feels like the devs understand PM and what makes it fun
-Visually, this game is gorgeous with a lot of polish
-The game is very good as guiding you without holding your hand
-A diverse set of cast and things to do
-The game supports a lot of replayability, with NG+ essentially in the form of a points shop
-You won't feel punished like in classic PM games or LLtQ for not knowing exactly how to invest in your daughter in advance
-Bisexuality and polyamory are neat things you don't get in a lot of otome games
-You get to develop a relationship with your daughter without Gainax's creepy touch
-The game did not take me a week during lockdown to no-life marathon one single playthrough unlike PM5

The bad:
-Despite the amount of things to do, you inevitably will find it stale after a playthrough or two. This has less to do with the diversity of options, and more to do with the depth of those options
-The game is so good at guiding you that there isn't really a lot of secret things for you to discover. Unless you're aiming for endings/romance routes, one playthrough where you dip your toes into everything basically will be all you need to experience everything
-NG+ makes it way too easy to get endings, but achieving any of the prestigious endings without them is pretty rough
-The combat is pretty unbalanced. Your girl's 3-hit DoT skill and Ze's stunlocking are basically all you need to cheese everything. I just brought Kenneth to tank hits for those two, and healers are a wasted slot.
-While not as bad as the infamous Steam translations for the PM games, it can be rough at time and makes understanding the plot a bit harder than it should be
-The game pauses when you're tabbed out. There is nothing about this game that happens in real time other than being forced to watch animations in contests.  
-You also cannot fast forward text in a text-heavy game that encourages replays. 

Overall the game was absolutely worth 10 bucks even if I only did one or two playthroughs (I did more. You're talking to someone who played through the behemoth that is PM5 in a week.) Also as someone who went "I want to marry Gwynneth. Oh, a lot of her interactions involve her brother? Let's also raise his relationship too," I absolutely got blindsided with a wiffle bat achieving THAT romance ending. Whether that's good or bad is up to you I guess LOL

137429947.review:
Fantastic stat building game with visual novel and lite RPG elements. Clearly inspired by the old Princess Maker games from Japan. If you enjoyed Long Live the Queen, Growing Up, or Chinese Parent Simulator chances are you will love this game too.

First play-thru takes roughly ten hours and each subsequent play-thru is shorter because you don't need to read all the text (and you know what you're doing!)

The Good:
* Dozens of Endings
* Each time you beat the game you earn points to spend to give bonuses for the next play-thru
* Many romance-able characters of both genders
* Devs have been really communicative and are fixing bugs regularly

The Cons:
* Repetitive Combat with a only few viable strategies and party make-ups
* Currently no skip functions for dialog (etc...) to speed up repeat play-thrus

Neutral:
* Translation - this has been a huge complaint from players. If you've played a lot of indie Japanese and Chinese VNs then you'll be pretty happy with translation - it's much better than a lot of games out there, and for the most part you can always tell what's going on. If you're not used to playing these kind of games the translation is going to feel really bad.

It's inevitable this will be compared to Princess Maker 2, take that as you will.  It's an excellent little life sim with a lot going for it.  Many practical routes you can take and lots of interesting possibilities to experiment with, although it might take you a little time to figure some of them out.  It also has a good little story at its heart that's appropriately heartwarming but not too overwhelming or turning this into a VN either.  Also a little chance to roleplay who the father is instead of being an invisible hand raising your daughter (not much chance, but significantly more than usual).

All in all: not a brilliant, groundbreaking entry into the genre but a highly competent one that I think delivers excellent bang for it's buck while pushing things a little further forward.  Worth a try if you've ever wanted to have a go at one of these and worth getting for your library if you don't know what else to get and want another.

137372710.review:
I really don't know how to feel about Volcano Princess. There is a lot to love here and I have enjoyed my time with it so far but there's one big problem I have with this game that endlessly frustrates me. 

[b] Overview [/b]

Volcano Princess is a raising simulator where you plan how your daughter spends their time which will consequently raise various stats. After a certain amount of turns, what stats you have will determine what ending you get i.e what profession your daughter pursues as an adult. 
If you're already familiar with raising sims, Volcano Princess is very similar to Princess Maker 5, another game that I love but wouldn't recommend to people. VP takes the town and character interactions of PM5 and applies it to the month to month planning basis of Princess Maker 2 and Long Live the Queen. It also is much simpler than those other titles as you won't be juggling nearly as many stats. I personally prefer the more in depth stat building that PM5, PM2 and LLTQ offer, however this does mean that Volcano Princess would likely be more friendly to beginners.

[b] Pros [/b]

The art is gorgeous and the presentation is generally very strong.
The combat is fun and doesn't feel like an afterthought (also Ze OP).
I like the cast a lot. Kenneth is my favourite, he's cute. 
Even though there are less stats, I still got the "number go up, brain happy" feeling.
The inclusion of Hades-style level ups to increase your daughters stats for the next run is a genuinely very cool addition.
[i] Some [/i] of the icky elements of Princess Maker have thankfully been left in the trash. Notably you can't romance your own daughter here and the CGs don't overtly sexualize her. I'm looking at you Princess Maker 2 and your vacation CGs.
Also your daughter can date girls!

[b] Cons [/b]

Let's get the ones that everyone else has mentioned out of the way first: bugs and the English translation. Once again Volcano Princess is very similar to Princess Maker 5.

For the bugs, the auto-save does a lot of heavy lifting here to avoid too much frustration as you will likely come across a game breaking bug or two. Also speaking of saves, it's very annoying that you can't save in the middle of a turn.
As for the English translation, yes it is very clunky. I feel similarly about VP's translation as I do about PM5's: very clearly grammatically incorrect however, as it's not broken enough impede on my ability to enjoy the characters, so I'm willing to let it slide. The only place where unfortunately it did negatively impact my enjoyment of the story is [spoiler] the ending where you beat up Owl Princess, Lebsa and Asbel [/spoiler] In summary, on a moment to moment basis, the English translation didn't bother me but it did get in the way of me feeling the full impact of the big story beats.

Ok so now for the big thing that's been killing the game for me: [i] why are half of the love interests so much older than the daughter? [/i]

With the exception of Craig and Nina the other love interests are either in their late teens at the start and adults by the end or well into their adult years. Like Hackett, my man, I love you but stop flirting with my 12 year old daughter, you're 19. 
It sits really badly with me and as a result I feel painfully aware of how much older these characters are then my daughter everytime I interact with them. And because the stat building is so bare compared to Princess Maker, most of the gameplay for me has been in interacting with the cast therefore making the problem feel even worse. 
Like, the daughter dating in PM is [i] bad [/i] and I hate it but at least if I wasn't actively pursuing it I could ignore it very easily. It feels worse when you consider that PM5 has a gross romancable adult  - the idol manager guy - but once again it was easily ignorable if I didn't pursue it. Here I can't bring myself to do that. It's especially frustrating because, like I've said already, game gets rid of other icky parts of PM like the daughter dating and yet why does it doubles down on this one?
Also as a side note, the characters who are of the same or close age to the daughter are very clearly not designed with being 13 in mind. If the game told me that Benson, Hackett, Mona, Rebecca and Gwyneth were only a year older or the same age as the daughter I would be totally willing to suspend my disbelief like I'm already doing for Craig. You cannot convince me that that design is for a boy any younger than 17 but again, I can suspend my disbelief. Or hell, if the game didn't tell me their ages at all I probably would've been fine with it.

[b] Conclusion [/b]

While I have been comparing Volcano Princess to Princess Maker 5 for most of this review, really my experience with it has felt closer to Little Witch Romanesque. While Volcano Princess is not nearly as bad as Little Witch - which I did one run of and immediately dropped - the gross parts are still too overt and unavoidable to me to properly find enjoyment in the good game and beautiful art underneath. And that really sucks.

After finishing one playthrough and being halfway through my second one, time for a short review:

I fell in love with the game when the first demo was out and the full game didn't disappoint my expectations. This is probably the one heir to the Princess Maker series that best captures what made Princess Maker II so lovely. 

The game is far from perfect. The english translation can be improved a lot and some areas of the game could use a bit more fleshing out. The combat system against the demons is among the most detailed parts of the game and it gets the job done just fine. It's about the right amount of complexity to keep you engaged without the battles becoming too tiresome. 

The music sets the scene just fine and some themes like the one at the volcano lake are just so adorable that I am always staying longer in the scene than neccessary just to let the tranquility set in some more.

The game had a few debilitating bugs at the start but the devs are quick to apply fixes and seem very engaged. At the current pricing you can't go wrong if you enjoyed similar games.
