i just finished my first run through (my play time is not representative of that, i kept leaving it open) and i'd say i conditionally recommend this game. if you're really into management and life sims like i am, and don't really care about a very poor story and translation, you'll have fun. I can't say I didn't have fun! that's why i'm recommending it, but you have to be aware there are a lot of cons, and that's not just in the translation/story. 

firstly, there are elements of the game that just aren't finished/don't work. the ending is disappointingly bare bones, and i know you're supposed to play it again, but after all that you just get a letter summarising her life. it's also VERY buggy right now. i had it crash a few times and at the moment you're not supposed to start the game without turning off cloud saving, which is disappointing for a fully released game. i know this is a very small team though, and i'm overall impressed despite all of this, which is pretty crazy, because there are massive flaws. i also found the (thankfully mild) sexualisation of the daughter uncomfortable... and why are all these older people hitting on her when she's 12 years old?

the translation being bad i mostly just found really funny actually, but there are times where it's a genuine hindrance, like performing in the theatre. i didn't understand what was supposed to be the 'romantic' options, or 'hopeful', or whatever, because they didn't really make sense most of the time. the same problem arises in responding to letters. 

also, i found the music repetitive and annoying, and turned it off pretty quickly to play my own music in the background. 

the relationship between the father and daughter is sweet, but again, the story is one of the worst parts of the game, which is a shame because if it wasn't, this game could be incredible. anyway, again, i'd only recommend this to specific kinds of people, if you're like me and just like management style life sims. it scratched that right itch for me. i also like that you can marry whoever you want regardless of their gender, but i'd say it mostly doesn't matter because all the characters are so one dimensional and all you get is a few confusing and poorly written cut scenes that i found myself speeding through from boredom. a great work of literature this is not. but a fun game? sure.

Loved the game enough that I'm 32 hours in (as of writing) and about to start my 5th playthrough.

 I love 'child raising simulator' games which have been hard to find in English. The 'Princess Maker' series aside, I enjoyed 'Long live the Queen', 'Chinese Parents',  and 'Cute Bite'. 'Volcano Princess' has similarities to these, but also includes a more 'fleshed out' world than I typically see, lots of mini-games (which range from 'that's cute' to 'thanks I hate it') MANY characters and an interesting plot. As is usual for the genre how you raise your daughter, which classes she takes, what activities she does, who she befriends and what attributes she levels up, will determine what possible endings are offered to her when she hits 18.

There game at release had many bugs, and one or two more were added when the old bugs were fixed. The dev team seems to be working REALLY hard to fix bugs as fast as possible, and have been responsive to community feedback, so I'm confident these issues will be fixed very quickly. 

The English translation has some typos and can be a little hit and miss. Having done translation work myself, I recognise it's more an art than a science. Some scenes and dialogue come across stilted because while the literal translation is there, it does not flow naturally. Occasional events, conversations or plot points can be pretty baffling for this reason. That said at time of writing the story and events are largely understandable, and the devs have made it clear that the English translation will see significant improvement, but with such a massive amount of text, this will take time. 

All in all I heartily recommend the game to anyone who enjoys the genre or wants to try it.

137323941.review:
Honestly, this was probably one of the best games I've played in a while.
I'm really into Simulation/RPG/Novel games, and I've had some pretty different experiences with these genres, but the feelings I'm experiencing with Volcano Princess are quite unique.

To be honest, when I first started the game, I was anticipating some sort of "Long Live The Queen" type of plot or adventure, but oh, I was wrong. Volcano Princess goes WAY beyond that, non only mechanics and graphics wise, but the whole feelings it's making me experience. It makes you feel deeply attached to its characters and NPCs, makes your curious about the lore and really engaged to its universe. It's a really good game with a overwhelming experience. 

The mechanics are pretty round, well developed and pretty simple to understand. I enjoy how you have many different paths you can choose and it makes you really feel like you have a 'choice' in your future.
Loved it!

137316833.review:
In comparing this game to Princess Maker 2, some things are better and some worse, but overall it is an inferior offering.  Still, that doesn't mean it wasn't a pretty fun game.  I enjoyed a first play through and then a new game+ for the "perfect" ending.

The attribute system is greatly simplified as compared to PM2.  In some ways this is a good thing, as it is much easier to understand for new players.  In some ways this is the worst thing about the game.  It's so easy to just max everything (especially on new game+) that you can make one character to tour all the top tier endings without much trouble.  This tanks the replay value as compared to PM2, where getting any top tier ending involved careful planning to meet the requirements and "just maxing everything" was a pipe dream.

The romance system was the same old thing used since original Harvest Moon, you can chat and gift people once a day, so no points for originality.  However it fits well in this sort of game, and it's as functional as it has always been.

One point where is surpasses PM2 is the UI.  PM2 was mostly just a set of lists that let you pick what you wanted to do.  In Volcano Princess, different actions are performed in different places in and around town, so you actually have to travel to those different places to do things instead of just selecting them from a list.  It gives the game a bit more personality and makes the game world feel larger.

Overall, while it is an inferior game, it's still a fun game.  I enjoyed my two plays, and while it doesn't have any replay value beyond that, it still made for a good 24 hours of game time.  I recommend it to fans of the genre.

I've seen a lot of people comparing this to My Life as a Teenage Exocolonist and Long Live the Queen, and I agree wholeheartedly, but I would also like to raise this statement:

This is the successor to Princess Maker 2 that you have been looking for. 

Not only do you actually feel involved with your daughter's life, but your daughter actually feels like she has autonomy in the things she wants and does, even if you are technically controlling them for her. There's many options in where to take her life, though not enough that it becomes overwhelming and every ending becomes another box to tick; every run feels special.

This is a great game if you were a fan of Princess Maker. I played Princess Maker all throughout my childhood and adored it, so it was sad to me when it was difficult to find games like it. Sure, there are handful of games out there that are well enough, but in my opinion none of them ever come close to Princess Maker... until Volcano Princess. Playing this game brings back that sense of nostalgia from my childhood, and unlike other recent games there is a clear true ending to strive for. It brings new mechanics into an old genre and it fits so well together. 

Now, I will say a few things. I really recommend this game, but I feel I do need to point out that out of the few playthroughs I've done now I have come across a few bugs. The most notable one is the fact that letters will come in  and if you click on it the words will not appear and it will break the game. There has been a fix created to help with this. However, another bug I came to was the fact that my game was seemingly skipping over the "Volcano Festival." I'm still trying to figure out if this has something to do with the fact that I changed my birthday month in my second playthrough and it skipped over the month of October because of it. Either way, it is a bug that needs to be fixed. The festival is a big part of the lore and gameplay, and it feels like your missing out when you can't even go. The game still runs fine regardless.

137258177.review:
This is an amazing game that is, dare I say, more fun than the original Princes Maker series. The game takes everything you love about PM2, and adds upon it. 

PROS:
Sophisticated stat system
Easy to understand
Areas in the town unlock as you progress through the game
Turn based combat 
Making friends that you take on adventures, each with different skills
Festivals that test your daughter, along with minigames
Wide variety of unique characters that feel like real people
Incredibly adorable father/daughter relationship. Also the option to be a bad dad
Lots of different paths for your daughter to go down, and  balanced with every gameplay
Unique story with its own twist. Choices you make heavily impact your daughter and story
Side quests in the Knights college that help advance your daughter in a certain direction
Lots of things to do in the town map
Romance is very in depth. The game also rewards you with gifts as you advance every relationship
Cooking and Crafting
Lots of straight and lesbian romance routes

CONS:
Dice minigame is hard to understand, even with the guide I'm still confused. I end up avoiding it every playthrough

Horse racing is very hard, even with novice races you have to have an extremely fast horse to win, which is not available until you have at least 40 MND. Also I spent like 2000 gold leveling up my horse and still couldn't win. Hopefully they make this more balanced

You can date practically everyone in the town. The reason I put this in the con section is because there are some weird match ups involving people a lot older than you, and you can start romancing these people once you hit age 12 lol. So yeah there are some huge age gaps and it gets kinda freaky for my taste. The only plus side is that you can't groom your own daughter like in the original PM2

No magic classes in the game. If you want to fight in the forest, you have to build up your STR, which sucks  because INT and CHA have no place in battle

This game is very long. It took me several days to finish one playthrough. I actually kind of like this because the game is very in depth, but I made it a con because some people may not like this when pursuing multiple endings

Battle requires a lot of grinding to progress, although they offset this by spending purple stones to level up characters not in use. The problem is that you have to grind to get the stones, and you can't purchase them

Overall I think this is a great addition to the Daughter Raising Simulator genre, and really scratches that itch I've been craving in a game for a while now. The only thing they could add to make this game perfect (imo) is the ability to decorate your room. I think it would be super cute to acquire different stuff to place in there to personalize it. They kinda do this with the Alchemy station, but you can't see any of the decorations visibly. That's just me though

137245769.review:
[quote=Anónimo]¿Es tener una hija el colmo de la cornudez? […] Piénsalo racionalmente. Estás alimentando, vistiendo y criando a una niña durante al menos 18 años únicamente para que pueda ir y ser follаda violentamente por otro hombre. […] Como padre, estás LITERALMENTE dedicando al menos 18 años de tu vida simplemente a criar a una chica para que otro hombre la disfrute.[/quote]
Venido de la china mandarina, tras una superexitosa campaña de crowdfunding, nos llega Volcano Princess, un PrincessMakerlike con un nivel de pulimentado propio de Gainax en sus mejores años… excepto que el equipo de desarrollo está formado por dos tías, posiblemente trabajando en un sótano de ocho metros cuadrados. Con un equipo tan pequeño está claro que la visión artística del proyecto ha quedado totalmente plasmada, si bien ha sido a costa de algunos errores en el apartado técnico. 

Pero empecemos por el principio; sabes a lo que vienes. Eres un padre, tienes una hija, y su porvenir depende de tu capacidad de navegar menús y minmaxear estados emocionales, conocimientos y relaciones.

Tras una breve etapa en la infancia, tenemos 4 años para convertir a nuestra adolescente en una mujer de tomo y lomo. El juego sigue una estructura mensual en el que cada mes podremos gastar varios puntos de energía en diversas actividades: explorar mazmorras, actuar en el teatro, tener citas con las 15 personas con las que queremos casarnos, plantar zanahorias, apuñalar vagabundos en callejones… lo típico. Dichos puntos de energía se pueden recuperar ligeramente, pero por lo general estamos bastante limitados (sobre todo en nuestro primer run), así que es mejor no diversificar hobbies. Esto obviamente lleva al hecho de que hay mucha repetición, pero seamos realistas, es un mal inherente del propio género.

No todos estos meses son totalmente jugables, durante unos cuantos de ellos tendremos que asistir a una fiesta o torneo que, por lo que sea, ocupará todo nuestro mes, a pesar de que el evento en sí no parece durar más que unas horas. Si bien me gusta que el juego tenga este tipo de momentos, me parece que deberían ser adicionales al mes en lugar de sustitutivos.

Al contrario que Princess Maker o Long Live The Queen, Volcano Princess opta por una experiencia mucho más apacible y sencilla. Por ejemplo, hay un estado que determina el humor de la chavala, y si baja del 50% sus stats se dividen por dos. Creo que son en contadas ocasiones las veces en la que eso me ha pasado, y arreglarlo es sencillísimo. El juego también ofrece un sistema de New Game+ bastante bien implementado en el que los logros que saques pueden convertirse en puntos con los que puedes facilitar enormemente tu siguiente run. 

También hay un stat llamado “darkness” que aumenta a medida que realizas acciones de dudosa moral, como trabajar de crupier para la mafia, o apuñalar vagabundos en callejones. Si tienes más de 50, se te niegа la posibilidad de usar una de las funciones más útiles del juego, por lo que suele ser buena idea no ir full edgelord. El concepto está bien, y hay unos pocos finales que dependen de tener más de cierta cifra, pero por lo general gestionarlo no es un problema en ningún momento. Ya que estamos, que criticar es gratis, hubiera estado bien si las interacciones con algunos personajes cambiasen en función de lo mucho que idolizas a Shadow the Hedgehog, pero que yo me haya fijado no se da el caso.

Y ya que estamos, hablemos de esos finales, que son a fin de cuentas uno de los aspectos más importantes de estos jueguillos. Hay mucha gente (entre los cuales me incluyo) para los que la experiencia Princess Maker consiste mayormente en “1 solo run, y que sea lo que Dios quiera”. Como en la vida real, si mi hija acaba siendo la emperatriz de la nación o la prostituta del barrio depende únicamente de mis decisiones y el RNG.

Volcano Princess cuenta con más de 50 finales según la profesión, a los que se suman más de 10 finales según la pareja ([spoiler]o, sorprendentemente, parejas[/spoiler]) con la que termines. Se queda corto con respecto a los más de 70 finales de Princess Maker 2, pero hay que tener en cuenta que la mayoría de dichos finales eran un simple sprite de la chavala vestida para la ocasión. En el caso de Volcano Princess, contamos con una serie de CGs de altísima calidad.  
Y es que éste es el aspecto en el que el juego brilla más fuerte. No sé si necesito decirlo: éste es uno de esos juegos que entra por los ojos; es supercuqui. La artista del juego tiene también el rol de “Producer”, y es fácil ver cómo esto es un passion project para el que ha tenido todo el dinero del mundo. 
Ya no es sólo que tu hija sea la hija más jodidаmente 卡哇伊 del mundo; a nivel estético el juego es una pequeña maravilla donde constantemente estás viendo arte que está ahí a pesar de no ser necesario.  El juego no necesitaba que muchos de los NPCs con dos líneas de diálogo tuvieran dibujo, ni necesitaba tener casi 300 items con sprites únicos, ni necesitaba tener 15 trajes (todos ellos supercuquis) que variasen en función de la edad de la niña, ni necesitaba tener arte en distintos estilos para cada una de las clases. Pero lo tiene. Una y otra vez me sorprendió, y siempre para bien, la cantidad de esfuerzo puesta en el apartado artístico. 

Ahora hablemos del otro aspecto; el técnico. Sí, ésta es la parte en la que le echo un pequeño jarro de mierdа al videojoco.

El juego tiene una traducción al inglés bastante pésima (aunque bueno, si sois fans de Princess Maker ya estáis acostumbrados a jugar a vuestros grooming simulators en inglés roto). A grandes rasgos se entienden las cosas, pero hacia el final el juego toca temas bastante abstractos y hay momentos en los que literalmente no tenía ni idea de lo que estaba pasando. Las desarrolladoras son perfectamente conscientes de que esto es el principal problema, así que es muy posible que se solvente con el tiempo. 

Hay algunas decisiones de diseño cuestionables. Por ejemplo, si tienes pensado explotar el sistema de granja, vas a tener que comprar mucho estiércol. Cada vez que compras lo que sea, tu relación con el vendedor avanza un punto. Es decir, que al final del juego no vas a poder hacer más que casarte con él. El poder del estiércol, nena.

Hay muchas cosas mejorables a nivel de usabilidad. Debido al cuantioso RNG llegará un momento en el que te tocará savescumear para intentar arañar la mayor cantidad de finales posibles. Desgraciadamente el sistema de guardado deja bastante que desear. Sólo dispones de siete espacios de guardado, y más te vale acordarte de qué estabas haciendo en cada uno de ellos porque la información brilla por su ausencia. Si bien puedes guardar en casi cualquier momento, al cargar la partida el día empieza de cero. Esto ya de por sí desanima al savescumeo, pero el mayor problema es que las cutscenes no se pueden saltar ni acelerar; vas a tener que desgastar el ratón como si estuvieras con el cookie clicker. Esto se convierte especialmente en un problema a la hora de sacar los finales. Lo que debería ser un proceso de diez minutos se convierte en más de una hora. 

También digo, muchos de estos problemas sólo te minan la moral tras 25 horas de repetición. Y posiblemente se arreglen en el futuro. [b]EDIT:[/b] Ya se puede acelerar el diálogo.

Por si no quedase claro, el juego me ha encantado. A pesar de sus fallos, lo considero de lo mejorcito que he jugado en este género, aunque para ser justos, tampoco hay mucha más opción. Para terminar de rematar, el precio es ridículamente bajo. Incluso si sólo quieres sacar un final y olvidarte, te va a dar diez horas fácilmente. Si tienes el más mínimo interés en este tipo de juegos and you can read english broken, tírate de cabeza.

137230270.review:
I'll start with reasons not to buy first, then jump to reasons to buy afterwards.

The music is stock music taken from a sound library.

The art varies from very professional to quite bad, but you earn that good art. The bulk of your time is spent in really inconsistent play-dough looking characters and randomly one mode is pixel art.

The game was in no way designed for English letters. The translation is so bad, and some modes, like the aforementioned pixel art mode, take quite a lot of work to get to.

I feel kind of weird about some of the outfits you give to her, that provide necessary stat boosts.

The game is mostly menuing without animations. This is especially blatant in the very optional fighting sections of the game, where enemies have very simple silhouettes and pop in and out of existence.

Cutscenes with animation are very ugly. Kind of hard to tell what's actually going on in some cases, especially since they feature the primary conflict of the game very early on.

The good

You're going to need to finish quite a few playthroughs to get all the endings. My first time, my primary love interest turned into an eldrich horror that made my protagonist pass out and forget everything. Kind of an intense ending.

Lots of romance options for the MC, it's like Harvest Moon on fast forward.

Art can be very good when it wants to be, especially the ending, where judgy kid Rose tells you all about your failures.

Load times are very fast.

Lots of options for playthroughs.

It's... a game for people who want to play a game about raising a kid. It's not a game for everyone, and probably not a game that I'll revisit very often, but I played it and I don't necessarily regret it.

137220714.review:
(Spoiler warning!)
Opening 
================================================================================================
My daughter was born on 23 April and named Jean. I must admit, this is truly a difficult start since early departure of my wife, but I must press on for the sake of our daughter, our dream. At her early age, we loved to went around town and tried everything we could do at that day. early morning activity was always go-to start for our plan. I knew, this wouldn’t lead to any further mastery in her future, nevertheless I wished she enjoyed everything that I could offer. 
As she growed up, she started to went around town and be a part of them. She truly one of the heart from the town, everyone is her friend. -heck, even i lost count, how many people has come to our house to see her (my guess is roughly 9, for romantic event). But it put ease on my mind since I got caught an unknown disease. At least, if it’s the will from the heaven to separate us on earth prematurely, she still had the town to rely on. But thanks to the heaven for he decided not to do so until the time.
My daughter wasn’t a champion but she was champion in my heart. She might not the best daughter in the world, but she’s the best for me and I hope the best for her. I’m proud of her, because she can be who she is and married to whom she loves.
Welp, actually, that’s my bad. I thought, it was better to had good term with his headmaster- Mr. Claude- so she wouldn’t have much trouble in school. Both of them took it too seriously, what a mess. At least, my advice, to cook first the ingredients, which come from her adventure, was a good idea. She becomes a good cooker and has her own restaurant.
And here I’m, on the first spring of this year without her, my wife reach home, which is truly a saving grace.
Also my transformation into a chicken is canceled, I don’t know why. I’m disappointed.
================================================================================================


Review
================================================================================================
(Disclaimer) This’s my first steam review. It’s worth to take note that my gaming history mostly in fps genre and/or something relate to world war 2 but recently, I want to expend my horizon. So, take my opinion with a grain of salt. No, a lot of them, not just a grain.
Volcano Princess is a rising-“daughter” simulation with visual novel and rpg frame. The players are tasked to raise her daughter whatever they see suit for her. Your aim is her future career and fiancé (and yes, you can make your daughter marry to other daughter, I tried this to avoid “cucked” feeling but failing due to academic reason: pleasing the headmaster). How to do it? Raise those numbers, baby~. Each turn, the player has a number of action. It can be used to do activity and replenished in certain ways. To end turn, player “plan” study activity for the daughter.
There’s a lot of arts, ton of them, and there’re good but due to the variety accessories, I find it’s insufficient and bothering. But this flaw is ignorable.
The voice is limited to just reaction such as laughing, thinking, etc. There’s no text reading.
The music is okay at bringing the mood, but I ignored it most of the time.
The rising elements (or the gameplay) is okay. Most of the time, the players raise her daughter through town interaction and planning system. I find this system is boring, due to repetitiveness, since most daughter actions are dictated by player options directly (not through father as mediator) and counted in numbers. I prefer to say it as lack of surprise element because it’s sureness (the authority of player and the honesty of numbers). % RNG isn’t the surprise element I mean, but the turning events base on choice like “Disco Elysium” (unfair comparison, but that’s the best I have). 
The story is niche, classic fantasy and a little bit of plot. I’m not sure how the plot turns out since somehow, I managed to avoid by achieve true ending. The good part is the light-warm interaction between char’s family. Other interactions are sometimes ambiguous due to translation, but still readable by putting few logics. Too bad, I couldn’t focus the story much (mostly I skimmed) because I feel uncomfortable with the UI. It’s my problem since I have encounter many similar UI and I couldn’t do much about my concentration.
The game itself is a little bit buggy. I couldn’t open the letter from friends (or I stuck with letter in opened position) and few times my games force close by itself, I’m not sure why.
Final verdict, I with reluctant to pick unrecommended but due to major recommended review, I decide so. I couldn’t recommend this game to past-self because my gaming history. Nevertheless, it still a good experience although at certain point, I want to bash my head to my keyboard so badly. I highly recommend this game to people that love raising-simulation, romance, and/or “visual novel”. If you’re a casual, I recommend you to wait for a while because the bug problem and translation issue.
================================================================================================

137204820.review:
This game is a lot of fun. Be a good dad and raise an awesome daughter. 

The game is similar to Long Live The Queen or My Life As A Teenage Exocolonist. 

You talk to people, give gifts, take classes, go on expeditions, farm, cook, work at a part time job, do alchemy, etc. You raise statistics through coursework, consuming certain farming outputs, consuming potions, buying outfits, or getting decorations for your house. Some combat specific stats can be raised through going on expeditions. Talking to characters you see on screen also grants a "perception" statistic / currency that is used when responding to letters you see if you have admirers, which can be gained from fame you get from attending balls or working as an actress, or from part time jobes at the bath with more sketchy jobs like card dealer for the mafia granting more admirers. The perception currency you get from talking to each character makes it worth while to talk to everyone and makes it so there are no useless character interactions in the game.

At the end of a playthrough, the person your daughter has the closest relationship with is the trigger for who your daughter marries as an adult. Your daughter may romance female characters if you to. Relationships with characters can be raised by chatting with them, giving them gifts, consulting them which also raises your statistics, challenging them to debates or duels, and taking them on dates. Dates so far seem completely platonic with some romantic undertones as nothing more lewd than handholding or hugging is shown (at least that I have seen in my 2 playthroughs so far).

As you play the game you will inevitably have accomplishments which are worth points at game end to make life the next time around easier. You can boost statistics, base relationship values with folks, boost fame, and get items for the next playthrough.

Like some other games in the genre, some of the "best" or possibly "true" endings are much easier to accomplish in your second playthrough with boosted statistics. There is some explanation on why the starting a new life narratively makes sense, but giving the specifics of why new game + is a thing in this setting would spoil the story. 

Current state, there are some typos, not enough to break the game, as the developer does not speak English natively. There are some bugs, that I ran into which caused me to need to restart the game. The developer has a discord and is actively working on fixing the reported bugs. 

I felt pretty good playing this game, I did not feel stressed out like I did in trying to get a good ending in Long Live the Queen. There are many endings you can get, and it is not the end of the world to get an average ending. Every playthrough can help you get achievements to boost your character in new game +. 

Oh, and the art is nice for the game. The seasonal changes in every single area of the game are nice.

Overall, highly recommend.

137202638.review:
EDIT: I am changing my review now to a YES! The devs have heard their fans and are working towards fixing the game breaking bugs. Whoever is still having problems with the corrupted save files even after trying to roll back the patch, all you have to do is;
1. Click windows + R and run %AppData%
2. Go back to the full AppData folder, the search will automatically take you to the roaming folder
3. Find LocalLow folder
4. Find Volcano Princess
5. Delete everything in the Volcano Princess folder. It is the one saving your corrupted save files. You have to delete all of it to get the game to work again.

After doing all of the that, my game is progressing again. Thank you devs for listening to us! I am leaving the old portion of my review below this.

NEGATIVE REVIEW
I really wanted to like this game. The concept is cute, the characters are lively, the overall game has so much potential. Unfortunately, this game has game breaking bugs. To the point where it is actually unplayable. There are several people complaining about translation issues, and sure the English translation could be better, but there are two very specific bugs that most people seem to be having problems with. The letters you receive from other characters and when you try to tame a horse.

The letter bug you are able to bypass by not even entertaining the thought of clicking on it. Unfortunately, the horse bug completely crashes your game and breaks it. I can't even play the game anymore. It won't let me get past the opening sequence. There are people who keep saying to unpatch the game, to force it roll back to the old patch, but it does not work if your files are located Program Files (x86). As of right now, my game is actually unplayable.

I recommend saving your money until these bugs are completely fixed. I will change my review until I am able to play the game again.

137173518.review:
TLDR;
Great Princess Maker-esque (or Long Live the Queen) game despite some bugs and iffy english texts. 8/10

The good: There is a lot of things you can do, and choices to make that will give varying results without being too punishing. Aside from story related choices most mistakes can be fixed as long as you're not going for a perfect run.
A lot of short mini-games to keep it interesting without it being a chore, since obviously you'll be doing them more than once if you're aiming for a specific stat.
Although I've only reached one ending as of this review, the story and ending was nothing too far from what I would've expected from the choices I made.
The visuals are good, cute, and fitting.

The bad: At the time of the review, mainly the bugs and iffy english translations.
I ran into a few bugs but nothing terribly unavoidable or detrimental to the progression, but there were times where I needed to restart the game. At least the auto save is there in case you forget to manually save.
The text is mostly broken or have grammatical/spelling errors, but most are comprehensible to a point. This may bother some and break the immersion. Nothing was broken to the point of making a wrong choice during my first playthrough.

Some minor QoL functions are missing, such as text skipping but honestly since most texts are short it's not the end of the world.
Both manual and auto saves start at the beginning of the day, so there is no way to save right before choices. But again, the texts aren't long so it's not that difficult to go back to the same spot from the start of the day.

137167343.review:
总体来说是一部很不错的类《美少女梦工厂》系列的作品。85/100

优点：
1，美丽的动态2D背景、细致的CG作画、悠扬的场景BGM，为整个作品创造了特殊的独特氛围感；
2，游戏中设计了相当多数量的子系统，每一个子系统之下又能对应多种不同的反馈机制，无论是人际/探索/养成，皆有独到之处，与其它养成类游戏能拉开足够远的区分度；
3，世界观的设计能明显地看出制作组所花费的心力，游戏的仪轨涉及渗透到了方方面面，完全没有让人出戏的突兀感；
4，程序设计非常稳定，全程没有出现过一次崩溃、跳出、Bug事件。

缺点：
1，女儿在童年时期的时间过短，印象里只有短短数回合，女儿就会进入到青春期，这让玩家的心流节奏有些跟不上；
2，某一些子系统的数值平衡仍然需要进一步打磨，无论是探索战斗，还是人际关系，后期基本上都存在通用解法，多周目游玩不免缺乏足够的随机意外和惊喜；
3，大反派的人物弧光过于突兀，没有成功地说明反派为何之所以是反派，沦为一个脸谱化的存在，游戏最终幕的呈现节奏也过于赶工了。

137160333.review:
This is the most blown away I've ever been at a game. I was expecting it to be some dumb poorly translated visual novel, and while it's still poorly translated (which only really makes it funnier, on top of a very funny game), what's mind blowing is HOW MUCH CONTENT THERE IS and also HOW GOOD IT ALL IS. I spent 11 hours on my first run, and noticed there are 58 ENDINGS, EVERY CHARACTER IS ROMANCEABLE (except 2, sorry dilf lovers) and there's a HADES-LIKE MIRROR OF DARKNESS SYSTEM. THIS GAME IS A ROGUELIKE VISUAL NOVEL????
I'm also blown away by how much heart it has. It really nails feeling both like raising a daughter and growing up yourself, as the game is split between playing as the father and as the daughter. The characters are ALL incredible, there isn't a single character I even thought was meh. The only problem I have with the story/characters is that there is SO MUCH that I can't possibly fit it all in one playthrough. Luckily, as I mentioned before, the new game plus allows you to start with a wide array of benefits like in Hades, which honestly is a very similar game.
As far as I can tell, there are 3 main "routes" you can take, which is basically strength, intelligience, or charisma. I went charisma on my first run, which meant I made a killing doing plays or working at the bathhouse, and can't wait to try the other two routes!
The combat is VERY good, which I was not expecting AT ALL. Like I said before, I did the charisma route, which meant my strength was lacking, but it was still really fun finding a combination of weapons and abilities that could let me triumph (burn is broken btw, it essentially gives you an extra attack worth of damage each turn, and it only accumulates)
I've been writing for too long. BUY THIS GAME, IT'S A STEAL.

137152565.review:
Very cute, played through one time at about ~6 hours and absolutely cried at the end. I currently have no intention to play again because the game left me feeling wholly satisfied with how things wrapped up, and I personally believe that to be a big plus. Totally worth the $10.

Translation is rough in some spots but not bad enough to affect my enjoyment, and the only bug I encountered was the (often reported) issue where sometimes when you click on a letter the game softlocks. Luckily exiting the game, reloading the autosave at the start of the day, and simply ignoring the letters let me keep playing, but still an inconvenience that needs to be fixed.

All in all, lovely experience. It's very pretty and the different ways you can choose to progress kept things feeling fairly interesting. There's a lot of stuff and a lot of alternate endings, so if you're the kind of person who wants to grind those out you'll have a good time. I raised my daughter well and she grew up to be an upstanding young lady so I am content to put it  down with no regrets whatsoever. If you like these sorts of management games, especially if you're someone who came from Princess Maker, I think you'll like it a lot.

137103731.review:
There comes a time in every man's life when he needs to take a look at himself in the mirror and wonder how exactly he reached such a place.
You have to truly ponder what decisions you have made along the way that brought you to the place of your final reckoning.

It is still unclear, even to me, why I purchased Volcano Princess.
There isn't anything wrong with it, with those nudity scenes throughout it's perfectly stellar. But when you look at it as a choice, you realize just how flawed you and the rest of humanity is.

What drove me to purchase such a game? What part of my soul felt so empty that I thought a virtual girl could fill it?
When I look into the boundless depths of my own loneliness I see a pool of reflection. My face isn't there, there is no face. There are only tears in that pool, tears of shame and loss and confusion.

If it were up to me again I know I would purchase it in a heartbeat, I know I would load it up and skip through the countless window prompts so I can have a single morsel of pornographic images which are readily available online.
Yet, despite the abundance of naked virtual women waiting in the digital sphere, I still chose to purchase this game and devote hours of my life to it. That time will never return to me, it is lost just like my soul and just like the time I fear I may never find it again.

There is something broken within me, something that desires sensation beyond my reach, something that whimpers every single night with the knowledge that there is no true Princess, it is a merely an illusion.
In my pursuit to find meaning in this long life, I sought the colorful lights and sounds of a world that only exists in a pop up window on my computer.

I am unsure what the moral of this review is, I am unsure about my place within the universe, all I know is that no amount of virtual girls can cure the vast rot that has overtaken me.

137082293.review:
Wish there was a so/so review. There's a lot to love in this game, but the English Translation REALLY holds it back.

Overall, this game is really fun. The characters are cute, drawn well and overall seem to have a lot of substance to them and some level of nuance. There's replay value in the fact that you can spend points from achievements gained on a run, to get higher starting base stats/items/etc to make the next run easier and hopefully to achieve that "better" ending or an ending that you are gunning for. 

The gameplay is rather simple. You have a certain amount of energy each day to do certain things, with ways of gaining more. As time goes on more and more, the character's daughter (your daughter) grows older with certain time skips at certain points throughout the game. You gain stats, skills, and subject scores in relation to the classes you take/the activites you do in the overworld. Or, instead you can spend energy fighting monsters in the forest, clearing out the corruption to hopefully find the "Owl Princess" to defeat the big bad. Or, you could become a socialite and try to enter nobility through social mingling. You can also grow food, catch horses and talk to citizens much like Fire Emblem Three houses did. Where you can talk, spend time with, duel in word play/actual battle, give gifts etc. There are certain activities like the "dark alley" that seemed put in last minute, that don't offer much to you and seem to be completely left field with art style. But not many have that issue. 

The music is very fitting for this game as well, and catchy at times though the lack of longer length tracks makes the second or third play through get rather depressing as once you heard the music once, that's it. 

The Arty style and art direction is great, the characters look awesome and the set pieces are well done with some art looking a little odd but nothing that looks out place (ignoring you dark alley, with your weird pixel based art)

But, all of this benefit, this great game packaged in a 10 dollar price tag is marred by the English Translation. At times it's passable, at other times it's so bad it's hard to understand why is being conveyed. As an example, during dates if you fill up all the "romance" points you get an option called "ambiguous." what that means, I'm not entirely sure other than you get higher rewards. 

I really love this game, I played it almost non stop for three days because I fell in love with what the game was, even if the English Translation was bad. However, not everyone will be able to sift through the confusingly structured sentences, the weird conveying of information and simply strange word translation that really hampers the enjoyment. At times, the translation won't even work giving the name 50C at one point for a character. To give the devs a lot of credit, it is only a two female team from China. The Translation at this point almost feels like a fault of the publisher rather than the devs. 

This game is easily worth the money if you can stand the translation, if that is concern give it a month or so and by then the translation should be up to snuff for any player. Easily one of the best games I've played this year, and I really hope a better translation comes out so I can truly appreciate what this dynamic duo was trying to make.

137046060.review:
This game is amazing so far after 3 hours of playing.

It's Princess Maker 2 but bigger, better, with more activites, the world feels massive and it seems you have a degree of freedom that all "rise simulators" should aim for.

I remember when I played PM2 that you were kind of "forced" into warrior builds in order to go to the dungeon and it made seeking arts, literature paths boring and empty. This my friends is completely fixed in Volcano Princess.

Seems you can even romance girls and you are not locked into marrying your daugther to male (haven't reached the end game yet of course but the option seems to be there and the girls don't shy away of being "flirtious" with your daugther)

Also, the game has a loit of mini games, you are into dice gambling you have it, you are more into rhetorical debates you got it too, "mini" farming sim... it's there, cooking game... you got it, random "loot" grind... yup you guessed it it's there too.

9/10 If you ever played Princess Maker series or Romanesque Witch or any other "rising sim" it's a MUST BUY. 

The only thing I would like to be changed is that the achievements menu is kind of a HUGE spoiler, I would preffer it to be hidden with " ??????? " naming.
